Learned on PNG 1310 & 1300. Went from standard to +Advanced and it made the foils so much more responsive and maneuverable for such large spans & volumes.
It took 3-4 sessions to adjust, I kept on trying to force the movements and had to learn to be more balanced.

I am 225lbs (102kg). Love the Spitfire 1030 mostly riding behind boats. Looking to add to the quiver and want a little bit bigger wing for smaller boat waves and pumping. Would the SF 1180 or Surge or Fireball be better?

Eric Lemay (240lb): I'm 240lb, wingfoil: Spitfire 1180, PNG V2 1400, ART V2 1099. Just got a used 1030. Didn't like the Fatty mast at ALL! Returned it after a few sessions, too much drag, too much interference from current. If you are on a 19mm aluminum, the fatty will be a small upgrade.

David Donovan Bunn: The SF1180 is a great wing for pumping as well as chilling on 2nd-4th wave back but not as much fun behind the boat on first wave as the 1030. The 1070 Fireball is a great wing as well behind boat and still very playful.
Jimmy Jam Foils: Surge 950 or bigger could be fun. Currently enjoying the 1010 and used to ride 1030 often.
Shannon Stent (70kg): The surges are actually epic for freeride style downwind. Just gotta match your size. I'm 70kg with 60L parawing board and use the 830 anywhere from 15-25kn
Mark Collins (75kg): Using 75 PC mast (not high mod). Notes 'bucky' feel, wondering if mast factors in at 75kg.
Steven Floyd recommends Surge 950. Zachary Sprunt recommends Surge 1010.

75kg rider on Frank 8'4 Mako looking for best foils for downwind in bay windbump conditions. Has Fireball 1250 - nice for flat water and pumping but too 'Bucky' when paddling up and too locked in at speed (using skinny stab on adv+ fuse). Hard to turn in bumps. Prefers HPS 1050 with progressive or skinny. Also has PNG 1300 v1 but not a turner in tight bumps. Question: what has replaced HPS for bayrun DW?
Thomas Roberts: I'm partial to the Fireball 1070. Great glide, turns well, fun to ride in general.
Koen Alloing: See if you can demo the 1010 Surge (3 likes - recommended by David Kelly, Shaun West)
Tim VR: What size skinny stab on the 1250, I'm using the 25 on the short fuselage, turns great
Andy Corbe: Surge 1010 is epic, the old Spitties 1100 and 1180 are also still pretty good, especially with surf stab
Sam Boufariha recommends Art Pro 1400 for downwind bay bumps
Duncan Wallace: Will probably hold onto my 960 spity for the time being. Need to test 890 first.
Baard Ulstein: With other words, Surge conditions! Looks like you could use one in the smaller sizes too.
Vangelis Evan M: The 1000 Fireball not really comparable to the 720 SF. You were way overfilled.

Taylor Gautier: After 6 months of riding Fireballs I can say my synopsis is that they are 'technical'. They require precise input and definitely do not like chaotic water. I put on a Surge 830 several weeks ago and haven't looked back.
Svetlana Galina: I thought Fireball was the best thing since sliced bread, a game changer. And now it is too technical and doesn't like choppy waters.
Steven Floyd: I thought the 830 was amazing until I put the 780 on...

Duncan Wallace (85kg): Rides SF 900 when windy (20-30kts) in waist to chest high wind swell. Asking what Surge equivalent is. Main goal is to carve swell but wants more glide. Is Surge better for downwinding than SF?

Tim Stockman: 890 Surge for your weight (85kg) would compare to 900sf, but Surge has better top end. I hear the 950 is pretty magic. I like more foil for connecting bumps so I'd just ride my 1010 in those conditions.

Brad McEvoy: I'm using half degree negative shim but just to reduce lift, not to balance foot pressure. I've also used a full degree neg shim and that was fine - just makes it feel looser and faster, without any real downsides. Also asks: are you using the advanced+ fuse? If not that will help move the foil back relative to the mast position.

Mark Shinn (AXIS top contributor): Shim advice - start at red 0.5, if still too much front foot add the 0.25, if STILL too much go to 1 degree. 1 degree is a lot... Regarding Surge vs Fireball: you will lose a TINY bit of glide but you will gain a tonne of roll and turn. It really depends what your goal is... Surge will give a more surf style feeling, Fireball gives a more carving feeling.
Adrian Roper (AXIS team): Works perfectly mid box on Frank boards. I have no control over where other companies put their boxes.

Phil Phan: Incredible session on Fireball 880 with skinny surf 300 on super K2 90L. Problem: mast all the way back but still too much lift, too much front foot pressure. The lift from this 880 is crazy. Don't have that problem with Fireball 1350 in lower wind (mast much more forward). Also: the Fireball 880 is so sleek! What would a Surge 830 bring compared to that wing?

Adrian Roper: One degree of shim on the rear would add front foot pressure. Minus one degree of shim on the rear will definitely decrease the front foot pressure. You really need to use positive or negative shim when describing shims otherwise it's just confusing.
Phil Phan: Mast is forward around 15 with Fireball 1350 in light wind, but with the 880 in high wind condition I have to move it all the way back. The skinny 35 is a beauty when it comes to glide.

Michael Kihn (72kg): Asking about Fireball 1500/1750 for flatwater paddle ups followed by pumping. Does the 1500 paddle up easier than the 1350? The stats of the 1500 make me believe it could be actually harder to paddle up than the 1350 whilst nicer to pump once up on foil.

Peter J Lataille (70kg): I've been paddling up the 1500 with the HM 75 and HM 82. I weigh 70kgs and it feels fine. You may be right thinking the 1350 might be easier. The 1500 feels a lot like the FB 1250.
Adrian Roper: 72kg you could get away with either on the 1500, 1750 more of a challenge. On the 1750 you will definitely get some wobble that you wouldn't feel on the Fatty mast.
Danny Perez: Great way to use old Art Pros. The Fireball and Surge made the AP seam obsolete. (DIY modification thread about repurposing legacy Art Pro foils)

Peter J Lataille (155 lbs, All-star contributor): Testing custom Fireball 1201. Flatwater pop was noticeably easier than the FB 1070, and a bit harder than the FB 1250. Pumping was fast and glide seemed adequate. Good low end. The Aspect Ratio is slightly higher than typical FBs - around 14.

Cyril: Fireball 1070 for UW/DW/freefly wingfoiling - truly incredible wing. Super stable with Skinny 35 + negative shim 0.75° (for better glide). With Skinny 30, Fireball comes alive with great whistling sound and feels free, BUT gets 'sucked' into nose down at high speed. Even +1° positive shim doesn't fully fix it. For everything else, it's truly fantastic. Skinny 30 not recommended for wings (risk of breakage).

Michael Scholes: Winging on 30 and 35 skinny with -1° negative shim on smaller foils (880 span and below). Recommends 280/43 surf skinny for Fireball 1070 - roll and stability in turns is better than 30/35 skinnies, but you'll lose a bit of top speed and glide due to decreased AR. The 300/45 only if replacing 35 skinny. Nose down sensation fix: get board with more rocker OR use smaller front foil (may be too large for conditions).

Cyril Grand-Guillaume: Strategy - 280/42 for maneuverability in waves, keep the 30 for calm water to maximize glide. Currently using Gong Cruzader Point 2024 with fairly flat rocker. Looking forward to Mini Dart + Fireball 1500 for pumping.
Adrian Roper: Small surf skinny could definitely help. What board are you using? Maybe this is too flat rocker? Surf skinny can take a beating too, great for surf or wingfoil.

Mark Shinn: I am often using the Surf Skinny 300 with the 1070 Fireball and recently the 1090 Tempo too, it works very nicely indeed... I am not racing and it does loosen the foils up and makes them even more 'throw around'.
Cyril: Surf 300 surface area = same as Skinny 35. The 280 is middle ground in terms of surface area between Skinny 30 and 35. Question: Is the 280 recommended for wingspans even smaller than FB 1070?

Greg Thomas: Fireball 1350 mast placement question. Also riding 1160 downwind with short fuse and 50 skinny. Problem: burning out back leg, board feels nose down when riding and pumping. Mast currently on position 7. Moving forward gets tricky (too lifty) or harder to paddle up. 19 comments with advice.

Denton Chase (Half Moon Bay crew): FB 1350 with Advanced+ fuselage, 560mm Crazy Short fuse + 35 tail. Mast position measured from Center of Gravity of board - front bolts 4.75" back from CG, pushing further forward to 5.25". This CG-based measurement is the standard way to communicate mast position.
Rory Baker: Centre of board weight is a couple cm in front of end of the tracks. Line the centre of the front foil over this spot - seems to work great. (5 likes)
El Pinguinito: Trying to get a grip on DW differences between Short and Ultra-short fuses. Currently riding Ultra-short. FB's are so nice!
Hazem Arafeh: I ride with mast position at 12 on 110 Frank board for FB 1350, 1160, and 1000.

Pete McCormick: Burnt out back leg will probably be your front foot too far forward. You need it forward to control the lift in the paddle up but as soon as you're up move it back a bit for riding. (3 likes)
Rory Baker (92kg): Same setup, usually have the back of the mast just visible over number 11.
Peter Michl (87kg): Also ride them around the 11 mark. Using the 75 high mod mast. No mast shim. 45 skinny.
Andy Tamasese: I ride an 1160 Fireball and put it between 11 and 12. That's a pretty sweet spot. If you're that far back you'll burn your back leg trying to hold the nose up.
Greg Thomas update: Moved mast up to 9 today and instant paddle success. Think I could move it one more maybe. (Was originally on 7)
Mark Shinn: I ride the 1350 on the 130 Mako and place the mast at 15. I suspect your mast is way too far back.

Yannick Favieres (95kg) - Fireball 1350 & 1160 Dockstart Test. Setup: 75cm aluminum mast, Physco Short/Ultra Short fuses, Skinny 358/25 and 360/45 stabs, Kubler 80 board. FB 1350 vs ART Pro 1401: bit more speed, HUGE difference in glide. 1350 feels much more responsive, playful, lively. About 10 tries to find the right start.

Yannick's son (35kg/77lb): Two attempts before taking off on FB 1350. Big improvement - more speed, glide, and maneuverability. Really loved the 1350 and probably won't go back to the ART Pro 1401. FB 1160 still a bit technical for him at 35kg.
Yannick (95kg) on FB 1160: No deadstart yet. But for parawing, it's amazing - super smooth, fast, and very enjoyable to ride.

Michael Thurmond (Rising contributor): FB 1070 with adv+ ultrashort and 300p. Board rides nose up on foil. Shimmed back with -1°, helped some. Found perfect neutral trim with standard ultrashort. Adv+ fuse needs mast 6cm forward to compensate. Using for winging, mostly upwind to downwind riding bumps.
Taylor Gautier: I suggest getting a skinny. I tried the Fireball with a progressive and it just did not feel right. Skinny is recommended for a reason.
Perry Hughes: I have a skinny 45 and prog 325. I find the skinny produces less lift than the prog so I always move the skinny setup back 10mm in the tracks (or a 0.5 shim).

Danny Cruz: If board isn't level when riding but feet are where you want them and board balances when hung from front foil, then what you need is a mast plate to board shim to adjust the board's angle.

Andrew Caska (86kg): Fireball tuning update. Tested FB 1160/1250 with p300 stab in low energy bay run. FB 1160 + p300 + adv plus ultra short fuse = 'perhaps the best overall setup I've tried for these types of runs.' FB 1250 was a touch faster but struggled to fit in short bumps. Uses FB 1160 for everything from flat water starts to 3:10 bay runs and 2:30 ocean runs - just changes fuse and stab (p325, p300, 45 skinny, 40 skinny, 35 skinny) to suit.
Andrew Caska (86kg) UPDATE: Stab for bay run is now Surf Skinny 320/48 (was p300). FB 1160 + Surf Skinny 320/48 + adv plus ultra short fuse = current bay run setup.
Lajos Papp (80kg): PNG 1400 v2 or FireBall 1350? For flatwater pumping distance. 21 comments discussing options.

Peter Michl: If your main focus is distance, I'd recommend holding off for a few more weeks. Something exciting is just around the corner. Tried one of Nicolas Iten's prototypes and was genuinely impressed. They're clearly committed to getting this one absolutely PERFECT. (12 likes) [Aug 2025 - likely referring to new foil series launch]
Vince Ridge: Do not underestimate the influence of the mast. Your alu mast not only drags, but also absorbs your energy instead of transmitting it to the foil.

Mark Holmstrom (98kg): Has and rides both PNG 1400v2 and FB 1350. Uses a+ ultra short fuse and 45 skinny. PNG 1400v2: more low end lift, slower, slower cadence, easy to recover altitude. FB 1350: higher speed machine, likes to turn more, comfortable with any chop or wind. For distance if already a good pumper: FB 1350 is what you want.
Joshua Hatton (100kg): Can flat water pump off boat wake but can't dock start yet. Mark Holmstrom recommends: Get the 1400v2/skinny setup for learning dock starts.
Angus Mackay: Depends on your age and fitness level. If you are older or not super fit, the 1400v2 for sure.

Mark Shinn: I use the 1400 if I have to paddle up or (god forgive) dock start. It handles low speed better. If I go flat water pumping but start with the foil drive then I use the 1350 as I have speed to start with.
Yannick Favieres (95kg): Asking same question about PNG 1400v2 vs FB 1350, currently on Art Pro 1401.
Halvard Kallestad: Seems like there's something coming for super long distance, quite a few videos of prototypes. They need to test fuse and masts handle the load.
Hazem Arafeh: Adrian mentioned in an interview that they were testing a prototype Fireball 1700.

Lajos Papp (80kg) flatwater dockstart benchmark: 6:20 time and 1650m distance. Setup: Art Pro 1401, 40 skinny, ultrashort adv+, 75cm alu mast, Kluber 80 board. Notes: Carbon mast would help, smaller tail might help, shorter fuse might help, but the most influence would be a new front wing.
Maxime Meyer: New prototype wingspan is more than 5'5" (Blast 95 length). Looks like 170cm. Crazy!

Drew Norman (145lbs/66kg): Just got the Fireball 1160 and this wing absolutely rips! Got it as a dock start wake/boat chasing wing. Compared to Spitfire 960: carves about 85% as well, pumps about 40% BETTER. Absolutely nuts for a wing of this span!! Might pick up a 1000 or 1070 next.
Jimmy Jam Foils on FB 1160: It's a good one. I need to use it more often for wake. Looking good on it.
Pietro Maciotta recommends ART v2 1099: Mid aspect is sweet in the wake/wave and still allows for pumping a couple of minutes to get the job done.
Thomas Roberts: Got a deal on FB 1250 but it seems a little big. Thinking about chopping 3-4 inches off each side...

Adrian Roper on modifying Fireballs: DON'T chop the tips! It will drastically reduce AR and ruin the tip out when turning. The Fireball wing tips are twisted off to unload the tips, and the very last foil section loft is symmetrical to reduce loading in the very tip. This allows the wings to breach without collapse. If you cut all this off it's gone. Cutting wings generally doesn't help. Fireballs are a great wing as designed - better to swap/trade than ruin your foil. (7 likes)
Fredrik Frekk: I run the FB 1250 with physco short fuse and a p250. That loosens it up a lot.
Tim VR on cutting Fireballs: You're turning something valuable to something worthless. (11 likes)
Andy Tamasese: What tail do you ride? That makes a huge difference (for loosening up a Fireball).

周宗傑: I own both the ART v2 879 and 939. Their span varies only slightly yet their roll behavior is already noticeably different. There are no bad foils, just different ride characteristics for different preference.
Peter Michl: Maybe try loosening up your setup with a smaller skinny rear wing first... or go a bit shorter with your fuse. (2 likes)
Peter J Lataille: I love the Fireballs, especially the 1070. (considering selling his 1250)
James Gabriel: Has ART v2 999, asking what Fireball has the same feel and low end.
Adrian Roper: Weirdly the 1000 Fireball has the same lift as the 999 ART v2. Maybe due to the span being the same. Area not a great metric to compare foils. (5 likes)
Andrew Caska: Personally I feel the 939v2 has more low end than the FB1000. I think it depends how you are using it. But at speed, the FB1000 can feel more lifty.

Tom Hovde (winging comparison): FB 1000 needs more effort and speed to get going than Av2 999, hands down. Av2 999 has noticeably lower stall speed, while FB faster, turns similar and needs more exit speed when tacking. Similar to Av2 879 with almost same area (790 cm² Av2 vs 773 cm² FB). Both span and area are relevant for comparisons.

Adrian Roper: The only true way to compare wings is to look at the graphs from simulation. Yes everything matters - span, camber, area etc but generally IMHO span is more useful as a comparison for area. (2 likes)
Richard V Taylor (80kg, age 51): No one has thrown in Fireball 880! Used to have ART 999 V1, have FB1000 that gathers dust. Also know two bigger guys on the 880. Don't be afraid.

Ry Stack: Have FB 1000 and ARTv2 999, used both extensively winging and foil driving. FB1000 has similar low end when starting but still go for Av2 in borderline conditions. Can save the Av2 with pumping at lower speed, but FB has to be going faster to save with pumping. FB needs more speed in tacks to avoid stalling.
Jon Verhoek: Something smaller than a 1070 for ART v2 999 equivalent. I've owned both and the 1070 has it for dead in the low end. FB 1070 has BETTER low end than ART v2 999!
Peter J Lataille: You would not be disappointed with a FB 1070 or FB1000. It outshines the V2 999 in all aspects. While the 999 might turn a bit better than the 1070, the 1070 can still rip turns.
Evan M and Yvon Labarthe both recommend: ART v2 999 equivalent = FB 1070

David Draffan (80kg) - AXIS Fireball 1000 Review: Wings 10-40 knots, quiver is SF 720/840/960. FB 1000 vs Spitfire: Different takeoff - Spitfire pops up, FB needs coaxing in light winds. Low end similar to SF 840. Super easy and stable once up. Totally balanced with skinny 360. KEY INSIGHT: Unlike Spitfires that get less stable at high speeds, the FB is OPPOSITE - faster you go, more stable it feels. 3 knots faster than SF 840 with no effort. Super low stall speed makes gybes effortless. Wind range 12-25+ knots. Medium wind winging all rounder - this is it!

Taylor Gautier (90+ kg): Demo'd FB 1000, daily is SF 840. FB 1000 has more lift than 840 but so much smoother, easier to control. Doesn't respond as quickly as SF when initiating turn - more stable but less carvy. Glide and pumping is a dream. Looking to size down to 940 or 880 for 30kt+ conditions. I'm 90+ kg on a 75L ML Armstrong.

周宗傑 (72kg) kite foiling: Uses ART v2 879 and 939, also BSC 740. V2 939 is biggest can use for 10-11 knots up to 15. More than 15 knots uses 879. More than 25 knots already overpowered on 879. For kiting don't need the glide Fireball offers. Strong wind/rough: prefers BSC 740 - very forgiving with limited top end.

Richard V Taylor (51 years old): Tried friend's FB 940, took off just fine like the 1000. Went straight to FB 880 - 'Wow! Now you're talking. Thing is a weapon.' Wound it up to 26 knots. When light uses 6m wing and FB 1000 gathers dust.
Phil Phan: I love the Fireball 1000, great do it all. I even use the 1350 for super light wind winging. Hesitating between FB 880 and small Spitfire or ART v2 for bigger conditions/larger waves.

Kurt Niiler (78kg): Looking for new dock start / flatwater pumping setup with maximum pumping efficiency. Comparing ART Pro 1401, Fireball 1350, and PNG V2 1400 - which is the best wing and how do they differ from each other?

Peter Michl: Spent over a year pumping on aluminum mast (19mm), switching to HM Power Carbon mast brought noticeable efficiency boost. The flex in aluminum AND in the 1401 is perceptible even when pumping straight - becomes a limitation when carving/turning. At 78kg you should be able to dock start without much trouble.

David Mahan: Has both ART Pro 1401 and PNG 1400v2. Been riding 1400 only this season. PNG 1400 doesn't extend foil time. It's easier to dock start and forgiving to ride overall, but not as fast and efficient as the 1401. Would love to try the 1350.

Peter Michl (~88kg) detailed comparison ART Pro 1401 vs FB 1250: Both really fast, not ideal for beginners on dock starts - need runway. 1401 noticeably easier to dock start than 1250. Stabs: 1401 pairs well with larger stabs (425, 365). Fireballs come alive with smaller stabs, crave speed and minimal drag. FB 1250 glide is 'absolutely addictive - arguably even better than the 1401'. Mast: 1401 needs HM carbon mast. FB 1250 fine on aluminum. 1401 has flex in wing, Fireballs are rock solid with UHM carbon - no flex.

Peter Michl final recommendations: Chasing max efficiency/glide → FB 1350 or 1250. Want ease for dock starts with short dock → ART Pro 1401 (pair with HM/UHM mast). Super short runway, want REALLY easy → PNG 1400 or 1200.

GeoVanee Daveed (70kg): Tried friend's PNG 1400 v2. Interested in ART Pro 1401 as it is said to be faster and more glide. Only has couple steps to run on dock. Asking about 1401 flex - is it a benefit or con?
Zevil Man: Can FB 1070 take off in 8 knots using downwind board for winging? Can take off using ArtPro 1201 in 8 knots.
Natanel Gluska (70-75kg): At 70-75 kg the 1070 with skinny 35 is just the most amazing wing for light & strong wind. For 8kts I'm using the 5.5m wing.
FoilBeat (78kg): AP1201 corresponds to FB1250, with the later a notch bigger. Setup: FB1250, Short Advance+, Skinny362, HM Carbon 900, 5.0m² wing, Cabrinha Swift 100. Works in 5-10kn at 78kg dry.
Jon Verhoek (92kg): At 92kgs I don't have a sh!t show on my 1070 (for 8kts). With the 1201 as reference it might be close.
Zevil Man confirms weight: 70kg (asking about FB 1070 in 8kts)
Evan M: I love the 1070 as an all rounder but for light winds I go 1160 or even 1250.
Giancarlo Jankie Avancini: Can compare the FB 1070 to the AP 1121 not the 1201!!! Zevil Man confirms: Yes sir, similar.
Armin Harich: Low end of FB 1070 is less than ART Pro 1201. I think almost 1 knt difference. The bigger ones are so great for really light wind. I love them. That should be my FB1350.
Mark Shinn (100kg): I agree that the 1350 is a light wind winging weapon and I am 100kg.
Christopher Green: Opinions on FB 1070 for behind a direct drive ski boat? Possible dock start with pumping? What's the best setup?

Erwin Morfe: I use the FB1070 as my daily driver for prone foiling. I tried dock starting the FB 1070 but had zero success. I dock start with the 1300 PNG V2. If you already have a good running dock start technique, you would be able to dock start the FB1070. However, it would be a bad idea to try to LEARN how to dock start with the FB1070. YouTube video: 'Axis Fireball 1070: a new favorite for winging and lake foiling--and ocean waves?'

Jimmy Jam Foils: Better off with a PNG or Spitfire for wake. Direct drive/boat wakes lose shape as boat planes out. Best bump at 10-12 mph. Fireballs like faster speeds but doable for boat wakes. 910b, 850 PNG, Spitfire 840-1030, ART v2 999 more user friendly for slower boat wakes. FB 1000, 1070, 1160 all doable behind boat - just need to keep up speed. For dock pumping, friends use FB 1250 and 1350. PNG v2 1200 is the new 1150v1.

Angus Mackay: FB 1250 is definitely the best size for typical weight rider if they want to do behind the boat and off the dock. You will have to do a few steps running to start the 1250 though. Also get a wedge or sacks for your ski boat. I see the 1200v2 as a learner, but I've never actually tried it so I might be wrong. It just seems too thick to use beyond the learning phase.
Adrian Roper: I seem to remember someone making the 1070 Fireball look pretty good behind the boat at AWSI.

Jimmy Jam Foils: Best to work your way up to a fireball but everyone chasing something different. Higher end riders are ripping on larger fireballs behind boats for sure. But I've seen some jump to an ART v2 and fireball and struggle at pumping cause they actually pump faster than the boat so need to be skilled to power up off the wave and then keep speed up. If you can do that, they rip hard.

Alan Taylor: Very surprised that the 1000 Fireball worked well behind my friends bayliner boat at 11mph on an AXIS tray. I was using an ultra short advance and a 375 progressive, crossing the first wake was very possible. We usually use the 960 Spitfire. I had tried the 1000 Fireball behind slow boats with a Foildrive and found the extra weight stalled out the foil a little too much but I might try again with the progressive instead of a skinny for these low speeds.

Jason Martino (OP): Fireball recommendation for a 100kg Intermediate Wing Foiler? I mainly surf in 1-3 foot wind swell and chop. So I don't want the 1350 as it would be hard to handle in chop. Also, I already have the Art V2 999. What type of difference will the FB make?

Tom Hovde: Got to test FB 1000 recently. It has a nice intuitive feel and higher speed potential than ART v2 999. FB needs a little more speed to get going and a little more exit speed when tacking. Good glide and natural roll. Maybe 1070 or 1160 if you want to add something bigger than ART v2 999?

Kyriakos Giakoumaros: 105kg I ride the 1000 in nearly all conditions. I am an advanced rider but its super easy IMO! Haven't tried the bigger size but I am loving this one. Also I have given it to our customers at Reckless Riders Wingfoil club and everyone loved it and found it easy to use!
Doug D PFoiler: If your local is on the lighter side go 1250 FB great big guy all around wing. If you're on the windier side locally 1070FB all the way.

Richard Windell: How I maximised my water time on my Fireball 880 Winging. I wanted to use the 880 all of the time in light winds as well. As they need more take off speed to launch, so I bought a mini cuda it's 7'4 by 19 inch 100 litres. I can now wing in very light conditions and I can go faster as the water is smoother and there is no need for big wings as it is much more efficient.

Thomas Boyce: In places with light wind, like Ottawa Ontario, about 10 of us build our own boards and very quickly caught on that board speed on the water means easier take off in light winds for smaller, speedier foils. We all ride boards that are 6+ ft long and 22in or less wide.
Richard Windell: 70 kg, 4.5 wing from 10 to 12 knots. Make sure you buy a v2 cuda, the v1's mast track is too far back for Axis gear.

Tim VR: I use my Axis gear on the V1 cuda all the time for parawing. No issues with track placement but I think this was only an issue with paddleups, not wing or parawing. V1 cuda is a good option to buy a cheaper board that might not be quite suited for paddle ups but great for winging/parawing. Parawing is easy if you know how to wing and don't try and go out in light wind.

Phil Phan: I have a Fireball 1000 and I love it, I use it for wingfoiling and kitefoiling. I mount it on a 900mm carbon mast with an Advanced Plus Crazyshort fuselage and Skinny 45. My board is a Drifter KT 90L. The lift is so high that I have it pushed all the way to the back of the board. About to buy a Fireball 1350 for extra low wind and dock starting. Wondering about smaller wing for more maneuverability kiting and wingfoiling in medium to large waves.

Armin Harich: It depends on track position on the board. I also love the Fireballs for my riding the most for kiting and winging and use also the smaller Fireballs up to 880. I just prefer a longer fuse for tacking and speeding at kiting.
Jake Libenson asks / Armin Harich confirms: Advanced + Ultra Short fuse + Skinny 362 is an excellent combo for FB 880 in ultra high winds. The smaller frontwings are good to handle with the Alu mast.
Alexandros Maragoudakis: Fireball 1000 is not for kite, it produces a lot of lift. Better the small ART v2 or 880 Fireball for kiting.
Leith Simpson: Yeah or tiny SF (Spitfire) or AP for kiting. Fireball has too much lift to kite.
Matthew Ross: I would think that FB 1000 would be way too much for kitefoiling. I am currently using SP 780 and ART v2 819 and could probably go smaller.
Chris Torckler: ART V2 819, Spitfire 720 or 670, HPS 650 all make awesome kitefoil foils at 85kg. The V2 is new favourite!
Alexandros Maragoudakis: But also 880 Fireball has huge lift (for kiting).
Alexandros Maragoudakis (Top Contributor): 1350 Fireball at 6-8 knots. Just want to fly. Using Reedin 6m wing (2024 model). Location: Salamis, Greece.
Leith Simpson: I predict more DW boards selling for winging in light wind than for actual DW. Imagine how fun that would be at anchor!

Darko Kastratovic: Axis Fireball 1160 is an awesome wing for pumping. It's got a really good low-end for its size, and the high-end is very good — it covers really fast. You can pretty much come to a stop and still pick up speed quickly, even in flat conditions. Setup: Board: DOCK 999, Front wing: Fireball 1160, Back wing: Skinny 362, Fuselage: Ultra Short Advanced+

Darko Kastratovic comparing FB 1160 to Spitfire: This wing (FB 1160) is faster and turns but bigger radius and you can't lean that much in curve like on Spitfire. But feeling under the legs is that the Fireball goes through the water much more efficient than Spitfire. With Spitfire you can turn around one dot (surf) and on Fireball it's more like snowboarding radius thing.

Alexandros Maragoudakis: THE MAGIC FB WINGS. I LOVE EVERY FIREBALL WING FROM 880-1350 FOR MAGICAL GLIDE AND HUGE RANGE. 87 kilos, 6/11 knots wind, 6 wing (almost with no power). With Fireball 880: very easy 42 km max speed, unbelievable, even no straps, no hook, so fantastic ride. Flying even at 6 knots.
Juho So: Wow. That is an incredible pumping skill too! I would not even dream of wing foil in such light wind condition even at my 76 kg body weight!
Alexandros Maragoudakis: With 1400 Axis I am flying even in 3 knots with very good upwind. Custom board specs: 2.5m length / 49cm width / 110 litr.

Alexandros Maragoudakis comparing FB 1350 vs 1400: I love both 1350 and 1400. The 1350 is not just faster, it's very fast, more technical and more stable in the waves and excellent upwind. The 1400 is very slow but this is the point - you fly even in 0 wind with magic lift, upwind. General if I have even a little wind I prefer the 1350 because it has more speed/less drag. Of course I prefer to have both of them.

Sven Chenbora: I guess the 1400 is for those low wind days when the other foils either wouldn't fly or only with mad pumping. I have a lot of very light conditions and just wanna be able to get out any day, so I'll get the 1400 first.

Andrej Marconi: What about tacks? I find very unstable my 'small' ART Pro's for tacks... and not funny at all. I am used to small foils, I just find ART Pro 1001 and 1051 too difficult and no fun. Paired with Skinny 40 and Ultra Short Adv+.

Alexandros Maragoudakis: The Fireball is much more easy for tacks because they have extremely huge speed range. As you see when I turn almost with no wind I continue fly even if my speed drops really low. But of course as bigger will be more easy. I do fantastic tacks even with 1350 FB.
Danny Cruz: I have ridden the ART V2 819 and the FB 880, and found them easy to tack and switch feet immediately.
Alexandros Maragoudakis: FB 880 is very easy with huge range. Imagine I use even -1.75° shimming and I am 87 kilos.

Stephen Zoio: I've had one session on the FB 1160 and it's the easiest foil to tack that I've tried so far. Of course great glide, easy to control the turn, and very forgiving if you run out of speed at the end.
Andrew Caska (Top Contributor, 86kg): Fireball 1160 & 35 Skinny. It was light so sized up today. Such a user friendly set up. Board: mini cuda 7'6.

Andrew Caska (86kg) on foil selection: FB 1160 - yes I can flat start it and I use this in light conditions 12 to 17 knots, once over that I change to the 1070. I have the 1250 but would use it in 8 to 15 knots or small wind bumps. For Foildrive I use the 1070 nearly all the time. Paddling I size up.
Andrew Caska (April 23, 2025): Fireball 1160, Adv Plus Short, 35 Skinny. Mini cuda 7'6, 20 wide and 110L. Rider 86kgs. Use case: downwind bumps.
Leigh Major: 95kgs 6'3" asking about paddle specs for downwind. Top of head height seems the go for DW foil. Andrew Caska uses 98 blade area - 'I'm a big boy and want power.'
Darko Kastratovic: WHAT DO YOU BELIEVE IN. AXIS Foils Fireball 1070 - Skinny 360. #foiling #foilinglife #foils

Cara Walther (51kg): I've been using the Fireball 880 and 35 Skinny tail for downwind wingfoiling in La Ventana. Very fast and fun! But want to try a setup that's a bit more stable for my back foot on tacks and slashing waves. I'm thinking smallest ART V2 819 front. Should I pair it with the smallest progressive? 250 or 275?

Vangelis Evan Mavridoglou on FB 880 setup: Go Short Adv+ fuse - it will give you more pitch stability and you can push even harder. Go Skinny 40 and that will give you more control. Go Progressive 300 or 325 and that will add more carving control. The Fireball 880 is an amazing front wing. Fast and predictable.

Simon Mander (73kg): FB880 is now my daily driver. I found a big difference between the SR35 and 40 with 40 being way more pitch stable and SR45 even more so. Also Short fuse is way more pitch stable than the Ultra Short (both Adv+). I've experimented quite a bit with SR45 and negative shimming up to -1.0deg also. The SR35 is ok in flat water, SR40 is significantly more stable and fast, the 45 stable and feels a little draggy hence neg 1.0deg shim which is quite nice too. I'd say Ultra Short and 45 neg 1.0deg is like Short and SR35 - once up on foil.

Filip Tvrdisic: For Fireball, Skinny works really much better than Progressive - simply too much unnecessary drag with P even if you go small. I found for me that the best skinny for all Fireballs is 360/40. For small Fireballs I go Short fuse, from 1000 I go Ultra Short.
Filip Tvrdisic (75kg): I'm using 819 with 300p, don't like the 275 or 250 but I'm 75kg. Definitely 819 will have more surfy feel but will not have that magic efficiency like 880.
Callum Hutchison: At 67kg I like the 250p with my 879 v2. Feels like more drive than the 35 skinny.

Chris Malanowski (All-star contributor): FIREBALL 1350!! Today was my first time downwinding the 1350, I used the Crazy Short fuse and a 35 skinny. I was pretty impressed that I could hold it down when the bumps got to about chest high. It also did a good job when the bumps were tiny at the top of the run. Given our local conditions, this is going to be a fun foil! Pumps good in the flat water and seems to handle a better range of conditions than my 1401 did for lighter condition downwinding. I'm sold! There were many bumps that I expected to be just completely over foiled for and would just need to hold on for dear life, but I was able to cut back on them and not fly out into space. A pleasant surprise for a big foil!

Denton Chase (Half Moon Bay, NorCal): I've been riding the Fireball 1350 exclusively for downwinders (mostly in no-wind situations) in Northern California since January. The other day was 10 feet @ 20 seconds a true beast of a swell and I was on the 1350. I am running the 1350 with 560 mm fuse, 40 skinny tail and 75 HM mast. PS: I have a 1070 FB but it cuts down my flying time because its harder to get up and doesn't glide as well. So why work when I can otherwise fly with the 1350.

Denton Chase (88kg / 195 lbs): I've gone down to the 35 but noticed a bizarre tail stall. Meaning I would feel little bizarre breaches but not a crash. I concluded the tail was stalling and the nose would drop and recover. Many times with the 35. But not with the 40. But I weigh 88 kg 195 lbs.

Tim VR comparing 1401 vs 1350: I did a back to back test between the 1401 and the 1350 on the flat. The biggest difference is the extra drag of the 1401, once it slows it's hard to get it back up to speed, but the 1350 will regain its speed without too much effort. The 1350 is quite usable in chop and swell where I find the 1401 a bit of a handful, being knocked around a lot more.
Shane Rodwell: Fireball 1250 vs PNG 1300v2! Two 10km bay runs, 1st 15-20knots then 2nd 12-18knots. 3:00 to 3:30 km's. Great foils for the conditions, super cruisey runs.

Andy Corbe: There's a big difference in learning DW SUP vs Kite foil in that fitness plays a big part. For me I could already downwind effectively with a wing to get going then mostly flagged out but it took a while to build the fitness to paddle up and pump. The wind died to almost nothing at times on that run so it's swell energy. It was pretty small, mostly knee high bumps but that's enough with the foils we have now.

Shane Rodwell comparing FB 1250 vs PNG 1300 for novices: The 1300 for sure. It's much more mellow and easier to get up and keep under control. I'm finding the FB very forgiving, but I've spent lots of time previously on the 1300v1.

Jonathan Robert (Top contributor, 67kg): Been using my 1000 Fireball pretty much exclusively for winging lately but today I thought I'd try out my poor neglected 951 ArtPro. Ultrashort Advance+ and 45 skinny, gosh it was fun! Felt slippery and alive, found I couldn't quite grave dig as effectively as I can on the FB 1000 if I got too low or misjudged a wave while flagging but I think that was partially because I've become so lazy with the Fireball knowing I can pretty much get away with anything. Realise they are effectively different size foils despite similar span and surface area, but fun to compare. Kinda liked the need to be 'on your game' a little more with the 951. Definitely still a place in the quiver for the Art Pro's. Totally torn regarding a smaller foil to replace my old 799 for winging and faster surf - Fireball 880 or Art V2 819.
Nick Howes: The Fireball 1000 wingtips are just a bit wide for me, and I'd like just a little more roll freedom.
Adrian Roper: Try the smaller Fireballs. The 940 Fireball probably rides bigger than the 951 and more stable.
Todd Brown (86kg): Great write up! Have 799, 899 and 951. Figuring out what foil I should be getting for a bit more low end lift.
Fredrik Frekk: Give the small ARTs a go. I ride the 751 and 851. Great foils.
Cameron Lenart: I found the 880 really nice coming from 951. Same slipperiness, better roll.

Paul McDonnell on PNG V2 1300 vs 1401: It IS easy with the V2 1300. I found the 1401 surprisingly hard to ladder-launch. I was only able to start successfully launching by throwing on the big 460 tail which this wing does not like at all. So it never became my go-to wing for ladder/beach/step off like I had hoped. Once going and with one of the smaller Skinny tails (tow up from the Zero Tow boogie or via prone surfing), it has exceptional glide and small bump riding abilities, and while I'm able to pump it further than any other wing, I felt like I was losing some energy to wing flex due to my heavier weight and stronger pumping style so I hardly used it. Traded it away for a Fireball 880 a couple weeks ago to test.

Paul McDonnell (85kg+/190lbs): Dead starting/stepping off the big Fireball 1350 VS the V2 PNG 1300 for heavier guys? Been looking and asking around but not getting any solid feedback. Looking for comparison in terms of dead starts, step-off starts, and beach starts with us heavier guys (85kg+ 190 Lbs). One of my favorite launches involves a very difficult cliff side step-off launch in surging waters that has to be nailed 100% before going on a 7 mile downwind run. The V2 1300 has been my go-to but would be nice to have the speed and roll of the Fireballs (have 880, 1070, 1250) and trying to decide if I should add the 1350 to my quiver.

Shane Rodwell: Fireball 1070 vs 1250. Loch Fyne, Scotland. Lots more wind and chunkier than last time. First go on the 1070: smallest foil I've ever ridden, stoked to have got up and had a great run, such a fun foil. 1250 handled the bigger conditions, managing a similar pace. High hopes for this being a 1-foil for all our local runs.

Andrew Caska (85kg, January 22, 2025): This is the Fireball 1160, 35 stab, Adv+ short fuse. A little over foiled in very tricky conditions. But, honestly love it. The 1070 is more my go to for my weight for 85kg - but the 1160 is a super light day session saver. I hand on heart recommend this to anyone who is or wants to downwind foil.

Andrew Caska beginner recommendations: Beginner I'd go 1250 for the ocean, and 1300v2 if you will go on a lake or bay. 1160 might be too slippery for a first foil. I started in the PNG 1300v1 for reference, at 40. I'm now 45.

Downwind Drifter beginner advice: Total beginners typically want the biggest foil you can get your hands on. These are not that, by a mile. You likely want the 1300v2 or 1350fb if buying new. 1401 if you can get it second hand for cheaper, big foil, works well for learning.

Vincent Lam (Top contributor, January 13, 2025): My take on the Fireball 880. I'm on the 880 (600cm2). I get up on foil as easy as the 899 (850cm2). The Fireballs are made of ultra HM, which makes it dam stiff, unlike the 1st gen ARTs. You can feel the difference. The 880 though smaller glides better than the 899, goes faster than the 699. So I would say an upgrade of the 999 would be 1000. It's 200cm2 smaller but I believe it will be able to get up on foil as early as 999, glides better and go much faster. Another thing, the stall speed is a lot slower as well, you can ride at very slow speeds.

Cameron Lenart: I bought Fireball 880 to replace my Artpro 951 (which replaced my 899). Has the speed (more?) and glide of the 951 but easier to control near its limits where the 951 could get wobbly, and can be turned tighter and snappier. Great foil. I just did a comparison of the Fireball 880 vs ARTV2 879 for winging and ended up buying the Fireball to replace my ARTPro951.

Simon Mander (73kg): I demoed the ART-V2 879 and FB 880 back to back last couple of days off Kohi YC Cameron in pretty steady 20-25knt E wind. Also used Short and Ultrashort Advance+ fuses and SR 45 rear with no shim and -0.5deg shim. I found the Short fuse really pitch stable using 45 with -0.5deg. Went back to Ultrashort fuse and tried without shim on 45 SR and actually liked it better than 700/45 shimmed setup. Regarding the wings - loved the FB880 was pretty rugged conditions (3.8m wing probably on day 2 could have used a 2.8m - I'm 73kg) was super smooth and controllable easy to steer and man the glide was amazing. The ART-V2 879 felt a little slower but I don't actually think it was looking at my GPS data, just more fluid and felt like had a lot of time to do maneuvers but definitely less glide, turns a little easier but not a big difference. I was pleasantly surprised on pitch stability of the FB going upwind. I would say I'm strongly leaning towards the FB for the glide/efficiency. Compared to ARTPro they are easy to use. The ART-V2 is really nice but for me the FB was more the style I like.

Simon Mander: FB940 is my daily driver now (just winging). I demoed the 879 in SW at Pt C in 18-20knts so flat water - was certainly more forgiving pitch wise and more fluid yaw/roll but less glide for sure than FB. I quite liked the 879 - I really like the 940! I think I need the 700 Short fuse (demoed that with SR40 with FB940) and it was a sweet spot for sure.
Vincent Lam: You will surprised how stable the 880 is with ultra short adv. Also go with skinny 45, I tried with 35, not stable.

Peter Blt (January 11): Hey team, a few thoughts I had on the Ti-link: As I expected it to happen one day - I forgot the cover piece at home... well the good news is the tempo actually still works fine without it no worries. Then, a bright shiny metal thing speeding through the water... is way too much like a fish bait and shark bait for me: I'll be spray painting black or white, too many shark attacks where I live. Anyways, those Tempos are so amazing, get one if you can it is really worth it!

Dimitris Apalagakis (73kg, SUP downwind, January 4): Tempos - the dream DW setup that puts a smile on my face in every single session! I've been riding the Tempos for a while already, 920, 960 and 1020 with 25 & 30 tails. The 960 paired with the 30 tail is my daily foil, 1020 for lighter/tricky days or super small bumps and 920 for the windier days. Ultra Pro mast. Huge range of use, ex: with the 1020 (650cm) I can go slow averaging kms 2:50s/min and fast sub 2min! Predictable: It's impressive that all this time of use, I didn't have a single unpredictable moment, not even at high speeds or big drops. Tempos are stable and super controllable, allowing me to push as hard as I want in any situation. Fast: these foils are seriously fast, I had my first couple of 30+km average sessions (960/30) on them, at not even the windiest conditions we get and felt easy! Easy: The tempo 960 (575cm) replaced my Fireball 1000 (770cm), I use it in the same conditions and have less drag, better glide and speed. Turn: The cherry on top is that they turn reeeally good for their span, AR and style!! They worth it!

Dimitris Apalagakis on Tempo sizing: The smaller the foils get, the bigger the difference you see in every size. For example if we had a 1950cm foil and then the next size was 1875cm, you would probably not notice any difference. But with small foils (I would say under 1000cm) is not the same! You feel the difference in every size. Yes I could get away with 2. So if I had to choose, at my size and the conditions we get (mostly wind waves, not powerful ground swells), I would go for the 1020 for light days and 960 (which is my favourite) for the rest!

Armin Harich: I don't downwind but bought the Tempo for Kitefoiling, Winging and eFoiling. I love them so much and replaced all of my Fireball in that size as it is a lot less drag, easier to ride and for sure a lot faster and nice carving turns. I just love them.

Sveny Foils (December 15, 2025, heavier rider): First session on the AXIS Tempo Wing 1090 last week and honestly, I was blown away. For such a high level racing oriented setup, this foil is incredibly easy and user friendly. I expected it to be way more demanding, maybe twitchy or hard to get up, but it's the complete opposite. The lift to get up is really nice, especially for a wing with this span. Once flying, it's super fast with heaps of glide, and it just wants to keep going. For me this is a big one because I'm a heavier rider and I don't have endless leg power, but the Tempo felt really comfortable and manageable the whole time. I've only ridden it on a 90 Ultra High Modulus mast so far. It's obviously not a turning focused wing, and that's not what it's designed for, but I know everyone still wants to see how it handles. What really surprised me is just how friendly it feels overall. Compared to a Fireball in a similar size, the Tempo feels noticeably nicer and more forgiving. All in all, a super impressive wing that completely changed my expectations of what a race style foil can feel like.
Sveny Foils on Fireball flex: I can feel it from 1070 upwards. I had a go on the 1350 today with the fatty mast and that was actually pretty impressive compared to the UHM mast.

Armin Harich (December 12, 2025): My Tempo Feedback - I have the Tempo 1090, 960 and 890 with the Skinnylink 360/45 and 35. I've now had 5 kitefoil sessions with the Flysurfer Sonic 5 (10 and 7.0) and the Supersonic 15, plus 2 wingfoil sessions on my lakes in South Africa. Usually I ride Fireballs and have owned all sizes. From the very first session the Tempo was a real blast for me. Finally getting rid of the additional drag. It actually rides even easier than my Fireball. It glides endlessly and starts surprisingly early. When you get a push forward by the kite or wing, it just accelerates with you. Pitch stability was surprisingly good, so I now only use the 35 Skinny. On the Fireball I usually needed the 45 Skinny or even the biggest Surf Skinny. I went straight from 43 km/h on my Fireball to 48 km/h on the Tempo 890 / Skinny 35 / Supersonic 15 — in only 10 knots of wind at the wind meter. Even in stronger wind I don't think I currently have the skills to go much faster. The turning radius is wider than the Fireball I think, but I didn't compare head-to-head yet. Because it's so effortless to gain speed, I can carve better with more leaning inward. Roll stability on the smallest 890 Tempo is lower with winging than I'm used to and prefer. With kitefoiling it was still easy to handle for me. Jumping is great and actually better than on my Fireball due to the extra speed I can generate. I couldn't test it with a Surf Skinny rear wing, as I forgot to order the rear-wing adapter. But it should help if you want tighter turns. For kitefoiling it turns tight enough for me. For wingfoiling and waves it could turn even tighter. Mounting and weight are really nice. It's a beauty how it is designed. I just love the speed and how easy they are to ride.
Andrew Caska: I've these the 1090 for parawing, so easy to use, fast and smooth.

Adrian Roper (AXIS) on Tempo fuselage: Equivalent to using the Advance+ Short (700mm), measures a bit shorter as no extra fuselage at the back to suit historical rear wings. We do offer an aluminium tail piece that fits the older rear if you wanted to use existing rears or mess with shimming. Shorter fuses? Yes but not required for current Tempo. Maybe one day if we have other front wings that could benefit from fuselage options.

Ohad Elmaliach (92kg, 180cm, wing foiler): Currently on BSC 1060 + Freeride 440 + 82cm aluminum mast. I really love this foil, but lately I'm starting to feel that it can be a bit slow, and in stronger winds (around 20-25 knots) it sometimes feels like it has too much lift. Looking for advice on how to progress within the AXIS system. I've been thinking about the Fireball, but I haven't seen many wing foilers using it, which led me to consider the Spitfire instead. Typical wind range: 12-14 knots up to 25 knots, from flat water to choppy sea.

Thomas Boyce (95kg/210lbs, Central Canada, Season 4): You are on the exact same path as I am on. I started on the exact same AXIS foil as you: BSC 1060. I spent 2 seasons on it and got everything I could out of it. It certainly has too much lift beyond 20 kts and is pretty slow. Next I got a Spitfire 1100. Great foil for me for the next 2 seasons. Again, I got everything I could out of this foil. Now I am always hunting waves and swells and downwind runs. The Spitfire turns beautifully but is slowish, has mediocre glide and is not the best pumper. The new foil sections and shape that Adrian Roper has been working on for the Fireball, Tempo and Surge Foils has totally revolutionized the AXIS foil line. They all have some similar DNA and have a huge range (glide like crazy & have low stall speeds). They all have great speed too. In my opinion these 3 new foils are making a lot of the older AXIS foils less desirable. So if you can only afford one or 2 foils, I have a feeling that most Allround, real world conditions wingfoilers and Parawingers will be choosing the Fireballs or Surges. I have a Surge 1010 on order as my next foil. I think you should skip the ART V2, Spitfire and all the others and try to decide between the Surge 1010 and the Fireball 1070.
Jon Verhoek: I'd also suggest stay away from Fireball coming from BSC. It will feel like a jackrabbit on a line of crack and redbull. Far too twitchy to make that step in one hit imo.
Glenn Beichel: I'd say V2 999 will give you plenty of options of wind and sea range and an advanced+ fuselage maybe an ultrashort.

Marty Jack: The Spitfires are a really good transition and are pretty capable foils. The Art V2's are a step up again in performance but also skill level required to get what you want out of them. Be careful going to the advance+ fuses. They can really make the control aspect a lot more difficult. The +20 black short is a really good step.

Thomas Thurnher (<70kg): Love the ART V2 999 for winging in mid wind range - also have Fireball 1070 - starts earlier/even more glide but turning and freestyle is much nicer with V2. Also have Spitfire 900, turns nice but less glide than V2 which is the golden middle of FB and Spitfire. For low wind the SF1180 is a dream - prefer to FB1250 and PNG V2 1300 - it has more camber than the other SF and turns so well with really good glide. Did not try the new Surge wings yet, should also have more glide than SF.

Perry Hughes (85kg): I went from the BSC 1060 to the Spitfire 960 with a Progressive 375 tail, it was great but I'm 85kg. Maybe the SF960 or SF 1030, if you can afford the Surge 950. Spitfires and Surge are loads of fun. Haven't ridden the Fireballs.
Jon Verhoek recommendation for 92kg winger: In your weight range I'd suggest either Spitfire 1100/1030, ART V2 1099 or the new Surge 1010.

Ian Sloan (75kg, winging): I just got off my second session on my Surge 830 and it is just so impressive. It's really easy to ride and very forgiving. I honestly wouldn't hesitate to go straight to it from your BSC. I've loved my ART899, my SF840, AV2-879, but this new Surge really is a phenomenal all around foil and easy to ride.

Danny Perez: I went from the PNG 1300 to the Spitfire 1100, 960, 780 & V2 999, 939 (plus a couple AP's). 1) Try out the new Surf Skinny tail, best upgrade for the money in the AXIS system. It has improved the feel of every foil I've ridden it with. It combines the best of the turning and playfulness of the Progressive and the speed of the Skinny. 2) The new foils do need a newer board. They are so much faster, but take a bit more taxi speed to get going. Went to a now ancient Kalam E3 and it unlocked the takeoff of the modern foils. 3) I haven't tried the new Surge, so it's all just a thought... If the new Surge is as good as the Surf Skinny, I'd say it's worth the risk of going all in and making a huge one time jump right for the Surge. *If you're looking for budget, plenty of great deals on used Spitfires and V2 are on the FB page.

Ian Sloan: Spitfire is a super easy to ride and really fun foil. AV2 is a little more technical but faster. I'd be looking towards one of these. HPS is also a great foil just a dated design, but still fun and pretty quick. There will be a lot of cheap Spitfires and AV2 on the used market with the recent launch of the Surge.

Noah Fraser (95kg): Another cheaper option, I went from the 1060 with big stab to a 375 stab which loosened it up a lot, then instead of going to the Spitfire 2.5 years ago I just dropped to the BSC 890 and eventually paired it with a skinny stab and have loved that set up for everything. I finally just ordered the 890 Surge as my upgrade but if you are primarily winging, dropping the foil size versus new design will greatly improve your performance. I'm 95kg currently and ride the 890 in everything and have loved it, can't wait to learn more on the Surge next.
Duncan Wallace: A progression that is typical is BSC to HPS to Spitfire. Others go ArtV2. You could probably skip HPS and go straight to Spitfire.

Dale Underwood (80kg): I moved from a larger slower front foil to the Spitfire 1030. I found it much quicker, more sensitive both in pitch and roll. All of which were good things. However, at 80 kg I found it generated a fair bit of lift especially when well powered. I'm now riding the Spitfire 720 which is so much quicker and easier to turn. I think you'll enjoy the Spitfire range. If possible try a few before you buy. I think that you will be able to get away with a smaller Spitfire than you think.

Danny Perez volume/area glide formula: Top glider Tempo 1090 (v:470/a:746=0.643), Surge 1010 (v:988/a:1076=0.918), Surfing Spitfire 1100 (v:1406/a:1423=0.988), PNG 1300 (v:1895/a:1712=1.106), PNG 1310 (v:2445/a:2070=1.17). Lower number is better glide. Higher number is more lift and beginner friendly.

Adrian Roper (AXIS): In answer to the original question there is so much information provided on all the AXIS wings compared with most other foils. We provide span, area, AR, volume in both American and rest of the world units. The one other thing that might help is the camber which gives you an idea of lift. More camber better bottom end lift but also can add drag. The foil section in the Fireball, Surge, PNG v2 all very similar and a key to why they work so well.

Andrew Caska (December 6, 2025): Tempo 1090 and 35 Skinny. I've really come to like this foil, so much so it's a definite favourite for anything over 15 knots or if there is some energy. It's a really balanced foil at speed and stays in control. Turns well, and gets better as you get the hang of it. Today had limited swell but 20knots, and I still did a fastest split of 2:07 min/per km with many splits 2:11 ish. But most importantly it feels good to ride, and makes downwind so enjoyable.
Peter Blt on rear wing selection: Only the Tempo Skinny 35 but I have always liked the regular Skinny 35 with the Fireball and the 30 felt too twitchy for me.
Andrew Caska: I've used the 1090 for long Foildrive runs too, once you get the hang of it, it's gold. So efficient.
Shannon Stent on Tempo glide: Still can't get my head around the glide on these. So much fun doing not much at all.
Adrian Roper (AXIS) on Tempo: So good to watch the Tempo videos and see the lack of pumping. Just glide.
Peter Blt: I love that Tempo 1020 such a good allrounder!
Peter Blt (December 4, 2025): Just tried a Tempo 1020 and they are really awesome foils! There's a crazy forward push that just keeps it going fast! Really amazing for downwinding!

Sean Richardson on Surge 830: Agree regarding riding the 320 Surf Skinny on the 830 at speed = low front foot pressure (not ideal going Mach down a double overhead wave). I went out today with the 830 and a chopped 325p in chest high point break - didn't think it would be my ideal stab - but it was still great for hold and front foot pressure when going down the line, and steeper drops. Will be looking forward to slightly bigger Surf Skinny for bigger waves... or might have to go to smaller Progressives again - maybe 275. Loving the Surge though!

Steven Floyd - Surge 830, 3rd session: Today winging on slow stacked chop and swell coming into Port Hacking with a run out tide. The 830 turns and surfs bumps so well. Can go straight and glide down waves or go into tight turning mode and push turns as hard as you dare your body is the limit not the foil. Low stall speed and pump ability at low speed allow safe recovery. Sails up wind with confidence great angles. Hardest thing going up wind is trying not get distracted and turn down a wave and surf it. Found I've had to move foil 2cm forward compared to the ART V2 foils to get enough front foot pressure this allows you to drive the sail harder and get reasonable speed. Gets on foil much easier than the V2 879. Foil pumps onto foil without stalling at low speed, where the ART V2 needed board speed to launch as it does not pump as well.

Enoot Oat (85kg): I'm 85 kg on an 80L mid length, and debating between FB or Surge in our lighter conditions on Lake Champlain. It takes about 18-20 knots to get consistent 1-2' swells. Not a ton of energy so not sure if I will get the glide with a Surge. If you are making the 950 work in smaller swell maybe I should lean towards a Surge as improved turning sounds nice.

Andrew Mitchell on Fireball vs Surge character: Yes 15-20 knots waist to shoulder high bumps. Both will be great, speed of Fireball will allow you to go up and over waves in front of you, Surge will be about going slower and carving the wave you're on more aggressively - choose how you want to ride.

Mark Shinn: Regarding speed... you are correct that the ART V2 has a faster top end - this is partly the shape (the moustache shape creates very conflicting lift vectors which = drag BUT it's also a design choice. Real wave riding wings are not designed to achieve too much speed. Wave foils are a lot about control with a good but not crazy top end. I have to say that I am loving the Tempo 1090 for flat water winging... so much speed and glide and a very surprisingly nice carve ability.

Steven Floyd (77kg, November 24, 2025): Surge 830 with Ultrashort Advanced+ with Surf Skinny 320. First impressions after 1 sail. 15knots of wind although felt much lighter at times, flat bay conditions. Been winging with Art V2 819, 879 and 939 since they came out. Weigh 77kg. Would have gone out with ArtV2 879 in these conditions. Insanity easy to get on foil with crazy low stall speed. Suspect as good as the 939... Just cant believe how slow you could go and still recover. Turns awesome. Turns with confidence better than the 819. Was happy just turning on any bump for fun. Tip breaches as much as you like. Can sail up wind with tips breaching continuously. Foil so easy to use you have to breach tips to have fun. Pumps glides great. Will be a surfing delight. Very easy to use foil as it gets on foil easily, turns confidently and breaches gracefully. Would recommend it as a learning foil. The 320 Surf Skinny felt great. For winging at speed front foot force dropped off as speed went to maximum so maybe could use a bigger rear wing? Only negative is drag at top speed. Did not have a GPS but it felt slow and draggy at top speed. Guess this is the sacrifice for amazing low speed lift? Suspect V2 drag is much lower at high speed. Prefer the Art V2 for sailing up wind and the Surge for sailing down wind. Dont think the Surge will replace the Art V2 especially for high speed foiling on flat water. Reminds me of windsurfing where the ArtV2 is a freeride slalom board and the Surge is a wave board.
Mark Shinn: The Tempo is faster by some margin. I have heard rumours of a wing race foil based on the Ti Link Fuse.

Andrew Mitchell (90kg): First go on the Surge 950 today on Parawing - at 90kgs feels perfect for the job, and agree, low stall speed surprised me and got me out of trouble a few times when the bumps disappeared - managed to keep it going till next bump appeared and I'm a pretty poor pumper. Also first go on the Frank Mini Dart - perfect combo.

Andrew Caska (86kg, November 16, 2025): Thought I'd share a few thoughts on the Tempo 1090. Ok, so, first run - I liked it but it was a step down in size and a step up in technique. It was an 18km ocean run in 15 to 20 knots. I would usually ride the Fireball 1070. Second run. Loved it. It's funny how a foil takes a run or two to click. This run was less wind (12 to 18 knots) but a faster underlying swell, and the Tempo was really good for these conditions - where glide matters the most. Turns well and handles quite wild conditions nicely. I think the main advantage for me is how free it makes your riding because of the glide and holding speed, so you can cut very well and kind of go wherever you want. It's good for up an overs too if you want to pump your brains out. So far I've got it to 2:16 and 34 kmhr max, but it likes about 2:20 to 2:30. Not dissimilar to Fireball 1070, but a touch faster with more glide. Using 35 stab and ultra 800 mast. I'm 86kgs. I'd use the Tempo 1090 is anything over 15 knots or if there is lighter wind and swell to ride. Basically, I'll be using the Tempo for all ocean downwind runs now.

Mark Shinn on Tempo 1090 speed: The 1090 has huge top end... I doubt us mortals will ever find it! I even took it kite foiling to try to find the limit, I hit 58 kph and it still felt that there was more there. For kitefoil I was running the alu tail pipe with a Skinny 45. At high speed I need pitch stability. For DW I generally use the Ti Skinny 35.

Adrian Roper (AXIS) on Tempo paddle-up technique: I can't speak for Andrew but for others that have tested back to back they have found the take off speed the same but it does possibly take a different technique to go from foiling to wound up on the Tempo. It likes to stay flatter and build speed rather than big changes in angle pumping.

Andrew Caska on Tempo technique: It lifts really early - but you can't stop there and need to get it moving faster - I found a lighter pump and using the paddle to take it up to speed was the best way.

Andrew Caska on Tempo 1090 vs FB 1070 sizing: Agree, I could not over power it. Top end is great. I actually want to try the 30 skinny now and see how fast it will go. In terms of size, on my first run, it did feel smaller to me than the 1070, especially in wind bumps. But, after a second run, I agree it is in the same ball park as the 1070 size wise. As long as there is swell, I'd take the 1090 even in no wind because the glide is so good.

Andrew Caska on Tempo paddle-up technique vs FB 1070: The first go I found it harder than the 1070 for sure. But after a few paddle ups, it is similar - it seems to be able to lift early but then you have a keep at it (paddling) to get it up to speed. It's like it has two stall speeds, an initial lift and then it cruise stall speed if that makes any sense. I found this when making a mistake too, I thought I would stall for sure but the foil kind of catches you and you can paddle out of a super low speed rather than pump out of a stall.

Mark Shinn on Tempo technique: I completely agree, low and fast is the key. In fact I found that initial when going from the PNG to the Larger Fireballs... try to punch them up into the air too fast and they wash out. The Tempo takes it to another level again, I try to stay close to the water and build speed until I can ease it up high, more of a finesse than a muscle up!
Liam Walton on Tempo 1090 vs 1020: Here's the 1090 I think it was. 1020 just takes more horse power and a little more gentle on the front for pressure at low end.

Mark Shinn on Tempo 1090 vs FB 1070: I don't agree it feels a size smaller... I find I can use it whenever I would use the 1070. The other thing I have found is that it is really really hard to over power.... The upper limit seems far in advance of any other foil I ever tested, not sure if that is down to the super high AR or simply the massive reduction in frontal drag that the Ti Link delivers. For stabs I have used the Ti-Link Skinny 30 and 35 and the alu tail pipe with Skinny 40 and Surf Skinny 300. Yes I agree for larger riders the 1090 or 1070 require significant commitment to get up but once up and running they are awesome.

Peter Michl (~90kg): It's hard for me at almost 90kg to paddle up the 1070 in average (non-nuking) conditions, but like you guys I am also a glide addict and would consider the 1090 to become my go-to parawing front wing.

Vangelis Evan Mavridoglou on Tempo for winging: I'd agree with both Andrew and Shinn. Coming from the Fireballs winging, the Tempo felt familiar right away, but it did take a few sessions for me to figure out its low end. Riding the Tempos feels very slippery and right away it pops up and gets into foil, with similar sizes as the Fireballs. But the gliding and pumping are different and it takes a few days to get to its rhythm. When it clicks, the Tempos are incredible winging foils. You will be riding faster than ever before and in full control. Always surprises me looking at my speed stats after each session.

Andrew Mitchell on Tempo 1020 for winging: Agree, been winging the 1020 a bit and the upwind angles are very noticeably better than FB... downwind glide / flagging a good improvement and downwind speed very good - doesn't hit a ceiling like you would expect with such a big foil - hard to get off it.

Adrian Roper (AXIS) on Tempo technique: Another comment to think on when transitioning from Fireball to Tempo, there are times when you feel that you need to pump to keep the flow but the Tempo sometimes runs better with less input. Next time you feel the need to pump maybe fight the urge and see the result.

Sveny Foils (115kg): I'm riding the 950 for downwind runs and for winging up to shoulder high waves. I don't prone much but if I would, I'd probably lean toward the 1010 over the 950 for prone. For winging though the 950 holds up fine for me up to shoulder high, maybe head high depending on the wind. In solid wind it works well from starting around 18 to 19 knots.

Sveny Foils on when to choose Surge vs Fireball for DW: It really depends on your conditions. For me here in Perth, I go more for a Surge than a Fireball because when it's windy over 20 knots with the sea breeze, the bumps stack up and it's so much fun to surf. I like a surfy wing for shorter downwinds on a Parawing where I do upwind and downwind, usually 5 km runs that can end up 25-30 km in total. Doing that, a surfy wing just makes it more fun. I definitely go for a Fireball if I'm aiming for distance, like a over 30km run or so, where I just want speed, glide, and to cover ground efficiently. But for short runs after work, up and downwind, the Surge is way more playful. The Fireball or Tempo comes in when speed and distance are the priority.

Sveny Foils - Surge vs Spitfire comparison: Right now, I definitely love the Surge for surfing and would take it over the Spitfire 100%. For me at the moment, it completely replaces the Spitfire. The Surge feels really easy to ride. It has a really nice lift, comes up smoothly without shooting you out of the water, and has a very low stall speed. Every tip breach, which was always a bit tricky on the Spitfire, is easy to control on the Surge. Another big advantage over the Spitfire is the glide. With the Spitfire, you really compromise glide on downwinders. You have to actively work it to get it to glide. The Surge, on the other hand, glides naturally from bump to bump. You can even slow it down on a bump and surf it. For how I'm using it right now, I'd definitely prefer a Surge over a Spitfire. It's incredibly user-friendly, really easy to ride, and fun.

Jason Hendsch (88kg): I'd like some advice. 88 kilos. Advanced prone, tow and winger. I want to ride more in the pocket and turn like a skateboard. I'm leaning toward the 890 Surge. Any suggestions welcomed!

Sveny Foils (November 19, 2025): Finally... the wait is over! AXIS has dropped their brand new Surge Wing – and it's a game changer for surf foilers. I was lucky enough to take the 950 for a spin on a surfy downwinder here on the west coast of Australia, and honestly... this thing is INSANE. Super responsive. Turns like a skateboard. Fast when you want it, slow when you need it. You can stay glued to the pocket or carve up high on the wave without outrunning it – it's just pure glide and control. This wing is a blast for: Prone, Winging, Parawinging, Downwinding, Tow foiling. ...yeah, it pretty much does it all. Highly recommend.

Charles Chandler (75kg): I'm interested in upgrading my surf setup. I'm riding long period unbroken swell, usually small, around 16 sec. period, usually less than .7m height, I use a Foil Drive assist plus to catch these waves. I'm riding an HPS 880. I weigh 75 kg. Do you think the Surge would be good for me? I have a black advance + ultrashort fuselage.

Sveny Foils recommendation for Charles Chandler (75kg): 100% you'll love it - would try 890, maybe you can go smaller as well try to demo one if you can. Surf Skinny 320 or 300. I think with your weight more to the 300 makes bit more, lose less drag.

John R. Coelho (79kg): At 79kg's; small to med Spit Fire's for waves and turbulent conditions, Art V2939 for clean / flatter conditions and HPS 1050 for light conditions. Any suggestions on proper Surf Skinny appreciated. Particularly for 939v2 to make more user friendly in waves and tougher conditions. I ride it on Blk Ad+ Ultra. Currently using 325 and 375P with Spit Fire's.

Jon Verhoek stab pairings: 300SS for 939v2. I've ridden 300SS with 999v2 and its super smooth and carvy. And the 939 with 320SS and also heaps of fun. Mate was riding 1030 with 300SS and seems to like it wake foiling.
Filip Tvrdisic (75kg): Art v2 100%
Lukasz Scibak: ARTv2 if person not too heavy, Big SF's if over 100kg for lighter wind days. For heavy wind ART v2 are perfect for all riders.
Steven Floyd: v2's rule.
Robert Ford: Art V2 819 as much as possible and 939 if super low wind.
Kyriakos Giakoumaros (105kg): Art V2s and Spitfires... for now!
Vangelis Evan Mavridoglou: Tempo 1020 / 1090, Fireball 1160, Art v2 819
Ando Flores: ART v2 🤙

Darren Zielonka: Wow, lots of Art V2, I'm on the HPS 930, 1050, or PNG 1150 on super light days. I'm mostly inland lake, inconsistent wind on the lighter side. I have the spitfire 960, plan to try that winging here soon, been my boat foil all summer. Putting the Art on my radar for wing!
Stu Molloy: V2 👍
Dean Bradley: Art v2 & spittys
Peter J Lataille: Fireball 1070/1250. Art V2 999/939
Sean Richardson (87kg): Depends on the conditions. For proper breaking waves - nothing better than spitfires - 780 and 720! For downwind swell riding and flatter days Art V2 939 and 819. I'm 87kg
Weston Van Wambeke: HPS
Armin Harich: Fireball in all sizes. V2 for waves
Vincent Lam: Fireball
Charles Bessard: PNG 1300v2 (8+ knots) art pro 1201 (12+) art999 (15+). With big overlaps but depending on the type conditions and activity, freeride, downwind, wave
Jon Verhoek: Art v2s and a big fireball for very light wind days. My 1099v2 just doesn't quite have enough for my fat ass
Bob Dunbabin: V2 999!
Janice Reed: Art V2's!
Chad Stewart (135kg): 135kg 1300V2 for 13-17mph over 17mph artV21099. Toying with idea of bigger FB for 8-13mph not sure yet. 1350FB is much faster than 1300 but just can't get up in marginal wind.
Stephen Hewitt: 900sf my go to with 45 skinny 😘👍15-35 knots love it
Kirk Gutzman: Hps 1050
Fabien Froesch: V2
Marc Stannard: Fireball
Joe Przychodzen: I upgraded from 325P to 320SS and love it on Spitfires
Brad Gordon: Small spittys
Juho So: ART V2
Tony James quoting Nader Boutros: ArtV2 for the win! Such a good wing, I like the spitfire a lot too and want to try the fireballs for our light winds.
Paul Hurley: Art V2 879 until the surge is released..
Adrian Taylor: PNG1310 and PNG1150 for light wind wing flat water and waves
Brad McEvoy: Fireball 880. The perfect all rounder
Tiago Dias: Fireball
Alex Vindel (85kg): Artv2 1099. 85kg, inland lake conditions 10-15kts winds. Really happy with it. Paired with 300 Surf Skinny
Doug D PFoiler (100kg+): FB 1250 lighter days, FB1070 windier days @ 100kgs+ like to add a 1000-1100 surf wing if they ever come out. Similar for parawing too except like my SF1180 choppier days
Javi Ro: wing free style artv2, wingsurf spitfire

Phil Daintree (kite foiler): I have HPS 650 which is great in waves (and HPS 700). I also have ART 699 which has similar top speed to HPS 650 but not as good in messy surf. Also I have ART 799 (a little slower) for light wind days. Wants FAST kite foil from AXIS.

Ryan Mrachek: Looking for stable freeride foil from AXIS. Everything is too responsive or has too much lift at kite foil speeds. Tried longest fuse and multiple big tails with small ARTv2 and Spitfires.. still searching

Chris Torckler: I went from kiting the 620/670 spitfire to the V2 819...even tho wider span it's definitely better all round. I did demo the proto tempo on kite as well as wing and it's fast and stable even tho bigger span again. Can't wait for some smaller sizes around 700 span!
Adrian Roper (AXIS team): Been working hard on a wingfoil race setup for a while now. Takes time and will be ready when its perfect

Vincent Lam: I have the R5, 751 and 880. R5 is fast, like the 751 but needs a lot more speed to pull through the transitions. The 751 is easier to ride, gets up on foil about the same as R5. The 880 is fast but not as fast as R5 and 751 but it gets on foil with a lot less speed, it's able to ride waves and pump, I would use it for racing if winds are averaging 8 knots.
Giancarlo Jankie Avancini: Try look for an Art Pro 751 much faster than the Art 699!
Shannon Stent: +1 for ART Pro 751! My fav tow foil wing
Mike Holland: Olympic kite foil racers are all on Levitaz by the look of it, you could get one of those if serious about speed with kite
Phil Daintree: Chubanga is the real answer for kite racing. Very disappointing that Axis has nothing even close and apparently no interest in kite foils
Annette Keleher: I could be wrong but the smallest tempo at 495 actual area and AR of 16 would go pretty fast?
Phil Daintree: Formula kite folks seem to have relatively larger stabs for control at speed. Certainly things get squirrely when I max out currently at 22kn on current gear
Vincent Lam: I would think the larger stabs generally give the foil more stability, I think it would also compromise on speed
Adrian Roper: DW and dockstart common to use very tiny rear wings. Wingfoil and kite foil often much larger rear wings as they drive off them

Alexander James Lewis-Hughes: I also tend to ride larger rear wings for surfstyle on a kite, smaller rears like you use for DW or some people prone wash out too easily with the added leverage/speed/drive from the kite.
Eddie Hawley: Have you tried the smaller Fireballs? They are so good at higher speeds.
Paul McDonnell: I've been surf foiling on the Fireball 880 which is the smallest one - area of 604cm. Even in small dribble waves. It's pretty versatile!

Leith Simpson: I have the AP751, AP851, SF720 & SF840, and a bunch of larger wings for FD (Foil Drive), and much as I would like one more, I think that we need a smaller mast and fuse to make it work efficiently, ideally with a 'magic string' type of setup. Agree the pros are all on Chubanga or Levitaz but I doubt that's a good plan until you are tacking and flying 18m vmg's

Darren Kite (72kg) - DETAILED COMPARISON: Back to back. 72kg rider. Small 2ft to max 3ft waves. Long bump groundswell rides from up to 500m out so you need speed. Ultrashort fuse. Skinny 40. Fireball 940, Artpro 951, spitfire 840.

SPEED: Fireball 940 fastest, Artpro fast. Both kept up with wave speed easy. Spitfire struggled to keep up with speed of wave. But switched on once the wave hits the bank. Hence its a pure surf wing.

TURNING: Fireball wins on long ride lines. Spitfire once the wave jacks up. The Fireball is still pretty surprising for surfing however. Art pro you have to initiate turn a split second and then let it turn, its not a surf wing; its a downwind or pump wing.

GLIDE: Artpro for effortless glide. Like standing up soul position let it run on the swell bump. Better if wave offering nothing. Fireball for fluid friction free speed, better if the wave offering a little more. Spitfire for a surf wave to slow it all down.

PUMP: Artpro for pure pumping

LIFT: Artpro, but Fireball better if you don't want that lift going faster in wave face drops. Lift down the face, Artpro starts to give more lift so in waves a bit much. Fireball no issue speed is your friend.
Steven Floyd: You need art v2 to add to the test..
Darren Kite: I think we have one actually, good idea (re: adding ART v2 to comparison)
Brad McEvoy: and would love to see how the tempo compares!

Armin Harich: Fireballs and Tempo higher lift foil section really well suited to DW racing but that's not to say that they don't ride great for wing and kite. Wings that are driven better suit a lower camber foil

Vincent Lam (Top contributor) - October 29, 2025: Has anyone winged with the tempo 890? How is it for winging and can you share how it behaves? How fast is it? Does it glide through the gybes? How fast does it get up on foil in comparison the 880 fireball?
