Michael Scholes (80kg) - DETAILED TEMPO 890 REVIEW: Tried it for the first time today, 890 tempo, 40 skinny link and 1050 Pro UHM at 80kg. Beautiful setup. Easiest way to describe it is the 880 fireball on steroids.

SPEED: First time using it and managed 31 knots top speed with 5s average at 30 knots and that certainly isn't its top capable speed. Even at this speed it was stable and wasn't too lifty. The acceleration is more remarkable - simply pulling in on the wing and you would suddenly jump to 25 knots.

GLIDE: The glide is better than anything from any brand I've experienced. Gybes, tacks, 360 degree carves it will glide through the entire thing with speed and ease.

GETTING UP: Getting up compared to the 880 fireball is harder, requires more technique (or power) and needs more speed before lifting fully out of water. Nonetheless it's still manageable even if you're slightly underpowered but will require skilful pumping.

RESPONSIVENESS: Once you're up you will notice increased responsiveness, roll and pitch require more precision in stance. If you're capable of riding the 880 fireball then the tempo isn't too large of a progression step. However, if you're use to 10AR and below I do think it will be a challenge.

WAVES: For waves it's a bizarre foil as initially you'd think it's too spanny and won't turn but it proved me wrong. Turns on a dime and can do reasonably tight cutbacks and turns without losing much lift (something the fireball struggles with).

TURBULENCE: Handles turbulence very well, was riding in and out of boat propeller chop and didn't even notice it, no instability, no loss of lift. Also works pretty well as a wake foil.

DOWNSIDES: No jumping (still a use for spitfires or art v2 for freestyle and heavy impact tricks). Looks and feels like a razor blade - don't want to hit it. Price with Ti link being quite pricey.

VERDICT: If you're after an unparalleled glide and speed machine that's still capable of surfing and being used in most wing disciplines then it's worth it.

Chris Torckler (84kg) - Tempo 890 Review: So after Michael's test run on the 890 tempo... This bloke whose knees are 45+ years older than his took it for a spin! 84kg and with a 4.5 Tao on a 100l axis hybrid... Blown away at how easy it was to lift once the wind pressure kicked in and once foiling has a crazy low stall speed! As bizarre as it seems it felt like lower stall than the FB or V2! Agile and responsive and explosive acceleration... Michael covered it all pretty concisely and I have to concur! Just be aware of the knife like foils and be super careful in the shallows or when getting on as they are sharp!
Michael Scholes wind conditions clarification: 15 gusting 20 knots. Started on 5m then went to 4.3m but the speeds I mentioned was on 5m
Adrian Roper on Michael Scholes: Michael is a talented local rider. He should be able to let me know quickly (about Tempo performance)

Shaun Henderson (75kg, Top contributor) - Surge 950 Review: Using adv +20 ultra, surf skinny 320, and 820 pc mast. Have now had 2 wing and 1 prone session on the 950. Im an intermediate winger and surfer all my life but newb prone foil. I previously would wing with Sf960 and am loving the surge upgrade. Faster, glider, turns amazing on bumps. I could not notice any low end difference but definitely better high end. A little harder initially to pump to connect bumps but think it was technique and will get better. Today was prone. Waves were head high out back then reform through a 100m trough, gradually getting steeper before breaking again on the inside about waist to shoulder high. The 950 was perfect getting up on foil initially and riding the reform big bump but as it got steeper before breaking on the inside it got very hard to control due to excessive speed. It's probably too big a foil for me on steeper waist to chest high waves.

Adrian Roper (AXIS team) to Shaun Henderson: I would think that for your 75kg you could happily ride the 830 Surge? I think the Advance+ (60mm +) would be a better option for surfing and not being overpowered. Advance 20 more a beginner intermediate fuselage. Luke Atkinson at 95kg plus rides the 890 as his main surf wing and can pump crazy distances on it
Matt Stockton (75kg): 75kg here, 830 is my go to for foil drive and winging waves then 890 when the waves are tiny. Pumping is amazing too, you'll be surprised

Doug D PFoiler (100kg): Yeah seems a bit big for sure at 75kgs, I ride my 960SF up to shoulder head high and it can be a bit much foilwise and I'm 100 kgs supfoiling when it's overhead I use the 900 SF seems to me you should be on a smaller wing in those conditions at 75kgs. Hear the surges have quite a bit lift to boot definitely need a smaller surge wing in the quiver IMO

Robert Sellar (70kg): Totally agree with what Adrian roper has said above I am just a little bit lighter than you at 70 kilo but advanced prone foiler and I use the 780 as my daily driver big or small so I think you'll just getting overpowered on such a big wing at your weight and when the waves that size and steep

Deon Aumaier on Fireball masts: You are not going to be happy using a regular mast w/Fireball wings. There is a reason Axis came out with FATTY masts and fuses. The stiffness of this setup is like nothing I've ever ridden.

Tim VR on Fireball mast pairing: Putting a smaller Fireball on a fatty mast is a waste and unless your a heavyweight. Fireballs are fast and thin, fatty masts aren't either of those. Up to the FB1350 the HM or Ultra are fine, over that the fatty is preferred. The 19mm alloy is a good stiff mast, no problem using that as an interim until the HM's become available again.
Peter J Lataille: FBs are fine with non fatty HM masts and smaller FBs would be fine with a 75 aluminum (19mm) mast.
Andy Corbe: 75cm Aluminium mast is pretty similar in stiffness feeling to 82cm HM mast in my experience

Denton Chase on mast comparison: I have been SUP Foiling all winter in BIG Northern California conditions (and small). I have been borrowing a UHM 90 cm mast, but then had to return it and switched back to a 90 cm Aluminum. I hate to say it but on a 1070 Fireball I DO NOT NOTICE any difference. Maybe this is good because it costs 10% as much aka $270 vs $2,700. For more typical downwinding I am using a larger FB 1350 with High Modulus 75 mast. But Aluminum has been working fine in the larger, faster more powerful surf.
Luke Atkinson (95kg+) mentioned by Adrian Roper: rides the Surge 890 as his main surf wing and can pump crazy distances on it

Cyril Grand-Guillaume on Skinny sizing strategy: My idea was to do without the 35 to have something more maneuverable in the waves when the conditions are like this: 280/42 and when the water is calmer, keep the 30 to maximize glide without having to push down on it like you do with a skinny surf in big. Using Gong Cruzader Point 2024 (flat rocker, downwind SUP shape). Looking forward to Mini Dart and Fireball 1500 for pumping.
Adrian Roper on Surf Skinny: Small surf skinny could definitely help. Surf skinny can take a beating too, great for surf or wingfoil

Mark Shinn (AXIS team) on stab pairings: Hey Cyril, I am often using the Surf Skinny 300 with the 1070 fireball and recently the 1090 Tempo too, it works very nicely indeed...... I am not racing and it does loosen the foils up and makes them even more 'throw around'

Cyril Grand-Guillaume - FB 1070 Stab Testing (Oct 22, 2025): I mainly ride UW/DW/freefly wingfoiling with the Fireball 1070 (a truly incredible wing). I find it super stable when paired with a skinny 35 and a negative shim of 0.75° (for better glide). I've also tested it quite a bit with a skinny 30 (even though this isn't recommended by Axis for wing). And then... the Fireball really comes alive, it's pretty crazy! When you're going full speed, you get a great whistling sound and you can really feel that the wing is free. On the downside, however, you get 'sucked' into a nose down position at high speed. Even when switching to a positive shim of +1°, the behavior remains similar, although the control is a little better/at the expense of glide, which makes the ride too unstable. Skinny 30 is not recommended for wings (risk of breakage). Wondering about Skinny surf stabs, particularly the 280/43, which in terms of surface area is right between the Skinny 30 and 35.

Michael Scholes - Stab Pairing Advice: I've spent quite a bit of time winging on 30 and 35 skinny, generally with a negative 1 degree shim and on smaller foils (880 span and below). As well as using the surf skinnies for last couple months.

I would recommend the 280/43 for what you want, roll and stability in turns is better than the 30/35 skinnies you will lose a bit of top speed and glide in my experience due to decreased AR so worth considering that. The 300/45 I would only recommend if you wanted something to replace the 35 skinny.

Regarding your sensation of nose down I would either get a board with more rocker as Adrian mentioned or use a smaller front foil. As it sounds like the foil may be becoming locked by using too large of foils for those conditions. Otherwise keep using the mast shim when you know you'll be going fast and forgo it on days you won't be.

Cyril Grand-Guillaume reply to Mark Shinn on stab sizing: The 300 must be great! However, the surface area is the same as the Skinny 35... My instinct was to go for the 280 to get closer to the qualities of the Skinny 30! (After all, it's right in the middle in terms of surface area.) But maybe I'm on the wrong track, and Axis is still talking about wingspan... Is the 280 recommended for wingspans even smaller than the FB 1070?! Have you tested the standard Skinny 35? That could confirm whether it's close to the Surf 300 or not.

Adrian Roper (AXIS team) on Tempo + short fuse: You would be perhaps the only one in the world wanting Tempos on a silly short. We have designed all sizes of aluminium tube but really not required with current wings

Jerome Mikeno on Fireball setup philosophy: For the Fireball, I find that the small fuselage and the small stabilizer allow for good maneuverability to be restored to a wing with a high ratio, not really designed for surfing at the base, but with a much better pumping performance than the ART V2. So I'm curious to be able to 'scratch' again in Tempo and have the best of both worlds: pumping/carving

Tim VR on FB1070 stab pairing: The biggest stabiliser I use is the 30 with the FB1070, gives great pump and turning but nice stability at speed. I doubt anyone buying the Tempo would use anything larger thus not needing shorter fuselage.

Jerome Mikeno on tiny stabs: I use the pk 50 ketos stab (50 cm2) in surffoil and pumping and the 85 for winging and parawing and sometimes the skinny 35. I had the skinny 30 but I didn't find it rigid enough and I was losing control... Yes, maybe the crazy short would be enough with the tempo. Uses FB 1070 and 1000 for surf.

Jerome Mikeno on tiny Ketos stab performance: Yes, there's an adjustment period, but the gain in maneuverability and pumping is clear. The Ketos stabs are very stiff, so despite the small surface area, stability control remains good

Ben Mcalpine (110kg, Top contributor) - October 13, 2025: Busted ART999 by jumping on it at 110kg. Message received that this foil is not designed for that. The problem is I am loving the jumping so much and I simply have to carry on doing it. My question is, what foil can I buy that won't break? Do I have to change brands? Those guys on youtube are boosting over 10 meters, surely something in the Axis range can handle my 2 or 3 meters?

Jon Verhoek on jumping foils: Art v2 999, or any of the ones with the 'chur' sign in the connection block are good to jump. Even 1099v2 is hi mod and ok to jump. But like what kyriakos said, just be wary of span, particularly on the older gen foils.

Dmitry Avramenko on jumping: I jump on spitfire 670 high. Max was about 9 meters. And never a problem. Tips: 1. Use proper low aspect ratio smaller wings. 2. Master the landing technique so that you don't really crash your weight into the foil when landing.

Kyriakos Giakoumaros (100kg) on jumping: Art v2, spitfires, bsc, hps - Most foils can jump it's more about the size and span you are using to jump. The guys on youtube and myself included do not jump big with any foils over 900span and also use small foil in general. I would jump at all with a 1030 spitfire but with my 780 or 720 I boost big without fear. In other words it's not the brand but the size you are choosing to do it with. Used to have the original Art 899 and jumped with that non stop. I am 100kg btw (probably more but trying to make myself feel good)
Mike Holland: Spitfire won't break (for jumping)
Reuben Williams: Spitfire 960 is the largest spitfire that has the thumbs up for jumping. I've got a 100kg mate who uses one in a decent wind.
Adrian Roper (AXIS team) on foil construction: Never EPS core. Various high density foam cores depending upon the wing thickness. The latest very thin Tempo solid carbon.
Adrian Roper (AXIS team) PRODUCT TEASER: 'New Sxxxxf wing should be great to jump' - When asked if folks will replace SF with surf wings for aerials, Adrian replied 'soon'

Tomer Shamgar (77kg) - October 13, 2025: Looking to add another front wing to my quiver, I currently own the V2 999. Trying to figure out if the FB 1070 would fill the downwind gap, or if I should go for a bigger size. The downwind conditions I'm aiming for are around 13-18 knots with choppy, rolling waves. I weigh 77 kg

Thomas Roberts on FB 1070 vs 1250: I'm really happy with my 1070. You would get more glide out of the 1250 but could become overfoiled if the wind/swell picks up. I went for a downwinder Saturday - Wind was 15-25kts with swell running 5' @ 10 seconds with lots of big chop. I did the same run a couple of weeks ago on the 1070 with 90cm mast. I wanted to see if I could connect more bumps with the 1250 on a 75cm mast. The chop made it very unstable so it was really hard to get going and when I was going it was very hard to control the foil. I have ridden the v2 999 for about a year and really like it. I tried a friends FB 1000 and it felt really close to the 999 so I opted for the 1070. I get a lot more glide and the 1070 will go very fast.

Charles Didier on FB 1070 vs ART 999: I own both and strangely enough the 1070 is more easy to paddle up than the 999 and has way more glide and pump efficiency. I only take out the 999 when its 20kts+
Jon Verhoek on FB sizing: The 999 and 1070 will be in a similarity ballpark. I'd size up one to 1160FB if you're looking for that lower power option.

Adrian Roper (AXIS team) on Ti Link design philosophy: The Ti Link was designed to allow us to create the very successful Tempo range of wings for DW racing. We have achieved that goal and I am sure in time we will have other suitable wings designed to fit on it. No I do not think the join system is suitable for 1750 span pump wings. The existing black fuselage is great for this. Equally the upcoming surf wings fit beautifully on the black fuselage. The Ti Link was specifically for development of the Tempo and this particular design with very very thin wings will not work with a big fat chunky carbon fuselage or our black fuselage. The expanding joins inside the wings provide a rigid connection that I don't think the Omen style fuselage provides. The whole Ti Link and Tempo has taken years to develop and I believe the best, albeit, not the cheapest solution. I think you really need to play with the setup to appreciate what it is. It provides another level of connection and is very thin and sleek

Luke Atkinson on Ti Link drag benefits: Also with drag being directly related to speed, I don't think pump foil and similar disciplines reach the speed where the reduction of drag is noticeable... whereas when you are downwinding at 30-40km/h the reduction of drag is obvious and going back to the black fuse feels much draggier
Adrian Roper on Ti Link geometry: Ti Link fuse length is equivalent to using advanced+ short in geometry
Adrian Roper favorite wing setup: I love the 1020 with 40 rear as my wing setup. Favourite
Dave Kissane on Tempo 1020: same. The upwind cut is insane
Adrian Roper on Tempo sizing for wing: Simon Mander asked what would line up with FB880 and SR35? Adrian replied: 940 or 890. My winging is more about upwind and DW
Adrian Roper on SS316 Link: Mark Duyvesteyn asked about plans for a SS316 Link? Adrian: way too heavy

Jon Mann defending Ti Link purpose: This link is made for downwind race foils, which they densely populate the top of the table... It feels like people are projecting their desire for new kit or projecting their desire for new kit onto something that's designed for something else then getting frustrated. I'm not even an axis rider. But it's impressive kit

Shannon Stent - Tempo FAQ (October 1, 2025): The Tempo is here! I'm going to get on the front foot and answer some of the common questions!

1. Is it for pros only?
A. No! So far the most common feedback is how easy it is to just jump on, and how it feels so familiar to the Fireball, just a little slipprier.

2. Will this replace the current fuselage system?
A. No! Although the new Ti Link titanium fuselage is sexy as hell, it won't be replacing the current system.

(Links to YouTube: AXIS Tempo Foil | Real World Test | Downwind RAW Ep 007 using 960)
Dave Kissane (84kg) on Tempo: The tempos will blow your mind. I ended up using the 'big' 1090 tempo in M2M. Seemed to be equivalent feel to 1000 fireball for me but I am a heavier rider at 84kg.

Andrew Caska on new surf foil teaser: I can't say much yet. I've ridden heaps of foils and brands and really liked it. Its turns rail to rail extremely well, pumps waaaay better than it should and glides also waaay better than it should. Will be useful for FD, wing, DW and obviously surf.
Charles Bessard: Ti Link price in Europe = 1050€

Shannon Stent on FB 1070 to Tempo equivalent: Christian Dittrich asked about FB 1070 one-foil-quiver for sup/surf/paddle DW, how does Tempo compare in small to medium surf? Shannon: the 1090 would be very close for sure
Adrian Roper on 2.1m span wing: Eirik Bøckmann asked 'Are you building a 2.1m span wing?' Adrian replied: 'maybe....'

Adrian Roper defending black fuselage: The black fuselage works great. The screws make the join just as solid day one or a year old. Having a carbon fuselage connection to the mast means that you have a very bulky fat fuselage join. Also the carbon on carbon wears over time and can't be fixed easily. I think what we have with the black fuselage is a great system
Adrian Roper on new surf wing and Ti Link: The new surf wing really would not benefit from the Titanium but would add cost to the overall setup. Maybe one day, case by case

Shannon Stent on Tempo quiver sizing: Most people coming from the Fireball 1000 are loving the Tempo 1020. If you were looking at a 2 wing quiver I'd probably say the 1090 and 960 would keep you well covered. And perhaps two rear wing options for in between tweaks. The 30 and 35 Link Skinny Rears would be ideal mate
Adrian Roper KEY SIZING: span for span about the same. So 1090 Tempo = 1070 Fireball

Shannon Stent on Ti Link fuse length: It's the equivalent of the short fuse, which really is the ideal setup for high speed foiling with a 16AR Tempo wing. This was tested over and over with our top level riders. I suspect eventually there may be some different lengths to choose from but I actually have no intel on that.

Adrian Roper on Dave Kissane Tempo conversion story: Dave is a great case study for the Tempo. I remember offering him to try in Hawaii. His response was nah I'm happy with the Fireballs. I run 2.2-2.3kms and happy there. I pushed him and he took to try. His response was amazing, so stoked. Less than a week later he sent stats on a ten km run, all under 2 minutes. It's faster no doubt but as Dave said, the options to cut way out and up and over easily completely changed the way he read the bumps. It really is something else
Dave Kissane recommendation for Sydney: I'm not easily impressed but these are next level. 1090 for Sydney will cover most bases. 1020 if you want to go real fast
Tiago Campos: Man I'm completely in love with my 1020. It seems to be taught 💪💪😍😍😍
Adrian Roper on aluminium fuselage manufacturing: aluminium fuselage all CNC cut from billet 6061 T6. Die cast aluminium would just snap
Tim VR on fuselage maintenance: you need to learn to look after your gear better. Coat joining surfaces that remain assembled after use with lanolin grease, rinse the glider after use.

Shannon Stent - Tempo 960 parawing performance (October 5, 2025): I took the Tempo 960 for my first open ocean downwind run. Using the Ozone Pocket Rocket 3.0 with a 77L Sunova DW board. It was a fast, glidey setup. 16km run with average foiling speed 24kph and top speed 33kph. Total run time ~40 minutes.

Mark Shinn on pump foil sizing: For me the 1750 is a pure pump foil, the 1500 doubles as a pump foil/small bumps DW foil. Happy to have both but if (god forbid) I had to choose one it would be the 1500 on the fatty mast and Psycho short fuse...... dreamy set up and sooooo much control.

Mark Shinn on mast selection for 110kg rider: the fatty is still thinner than the alu mast and many people use that for dw and winging. At 110 kg I would say fatty all the way... the difference in stiffness is significant and the increase in drag minimal.
Armin Harich (84kg) on mast for 1500/1750: not a must. I am 84kg and prefer the 1500 with my ultra modular 90 for winging. The 1750 I can ride on both masts but than fat is easier. Ultra still works

Nicolas Iten on fatty mast: Over 80kg yes. Better stiffness means also better energy transfer = better speed and control although the mast is more bulky. And don't worry about loosing a foil due to cracked fuse or mast
Tim VR on 1500/1750 mast requirements for 72kg rider: I think the 1500 will work ok with the Ultra, but the 1750 needs the Fatty.

Adrian Roper on Tempo vs Fireball pump wings: completely different animals so no crossover really. Tempo optimized for DW race but actually really friendly to use for intermediate riders, they cross over into wingfoil parawing nicely. The 1500 Fireball is a fast pump wing that crosses over into micro bump DW. The 1750 a distance low energy record pump wing
Adrian Roper on fatty fuselage compatibility: you can only use the fatty fuselage with a fatty mast. At your weight (72kg) you can likely use your existing mast and fuselage

Nicolas Iten (69kg) pump foil comparison: Pumped the 1750 2 weeks ago before my holidays. Same or less effort as my 1700 older proto, with which I pumped 4:25h, but 1kmh faster. The 1500 which I pumped 20.13km in 1 hour is faster but needs more effort (never went to the max time, I estimate 2h+). I'm quite good trained, but not a hell of a pro Ironman triathlete

Nicolas Iten (69kg) on 1500 speed: With my 69kg weight I don't have the top speed power, I felt a bit faster on the 1500 than 1350. The 1h I did between 2:55 and 3:00/km but can go slower to 3:40/km. Maxspeed I never really tested on short sprints, only 1km around 22kmh

Adrian Roper on Fatty mast: The Fatty mast a great example of a product that is affordable. The downside is that it's fat at 18.1mm but zero issue if you're a bigger rider on a bigger span wing. If you are riding smaller wings it's not necessary
Adrian Roper confirms Fatty is stiffest mast: Nick Burfitt asked 'is the fatty now the stiffest Axis mast?' Adrian replied: 'yes by far'
Adrian Roper on 1500 design: absolutely not just a scaled up. Much higher AR to achieve a benefit over the 1350

Nicolas Iten on 1750 vs Condor XL comparison (69kg): Did test last year between Condor XL and 1700 Axis proto. Heartrate was more or less the same (did with both wings 18km within 2.5 hours), speed was 1.5-2kmh faster, more pitchy, better turn. 1750 was again 1kmh faster than 1700 proto and same effort, 100% stiff and direct feeling with the fatty mast
Nicolas Iten mast recommendation: I highly recommend the 1750 with fatty mast/fuse, it is suuuper stiff and stiff means better energy transfer. The 1500 could be ok with UHM and under 80kg.

Chris Malanowski (34 yo, 175lbs/79kg): I pumped the 1500 for about 20 minutes. I'd say I'm middle of the road when you consider athletes like Nicolas Iten at one end of the spectrum and a complete beginner at the other.

Adrian Roper on Tempo use cases and disciplines (September 30, 2025): The Tempo designed primarily for competition DW race and excel at this. They also ride really amazingly well for average DW guys. Easy to ride, faster and give options to cut across bumps and up and over more easily. They are also fantastic for Parawing, Wingfoil and weirdly good for glide surfing. We have not tested kitefoil and I suspect still too large of a span but could well be proven wrong. They do keep surprising as to what they do well

Adrian Roper on Tempo vs Fireball technical difficulty: Charles Bessard asked if Tempo is more technical to ride than the Fireball. Adrian: not really any more technical to ride but like letting the handbrake off.

Yvon Labarthe (AXIS team) - Surge 1010 YouTube review (translated from French): First impression in warm water (16°C+) - pumping seemed quite simple. In cold 7°C water - totally different sport, quite energy-demanding for pumping. Turning is AMAZING - so well it surprises me, takes some adaptation. Skill level: Good intermediate required. Dock start: Similar to Fireball 1070-1100 range. Pumping technique: Different from Fireball, more subtle movements needed, less flat pumping. Best use: 500m spot with good waves = SUPER wing. For long downwind (did 20km twice): Would be more comfortable on Fireball which has broader use case. Summary: Great for short punchy spots with good waves, for long DW stick with Fireball.

Andy Corbe - ART 999 vs HPS 930 comparison (November 6, 2021): First run on the 999, 20km downwinder in 25-30 knots with good size wind swell, ultrashort fuse with 420 tail. I must admit after reading all the reviews I was a little underwhelmed. I haven't breached so many times in many a session, and found the pressure quite high which made it tiring. I've mostly been riding the HPS 930 and find it more controlled at speed while on the wave. They come up about the same. Top speed on the waves was around 16 knots, same as HPS, glide was a bit better but I feel like its a close call and HPS is more agile. One thing is for sure the new wings are amazing, massive respect to Adrian and Co.
Adrian Roper on ART 999 tuning: just slide the whole foil back around 35-40mm, as it has less sweep it needs to go back a bit. no need shims
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Andy Corbe (78kg) back-to-back ART999 vs HPS930 comparison: 2 hour session off the beach, first half on the ART999 and second HPS930. Mast all the way back for 999, 3cm forward for 930. For my preferences the clear winner is the 930, it is just so much more playful. Our waves are often in channels where wind opposite tide creates quite steep bumps that form and change quickly so the ability to flick around is key and that's where the HPS excels, it just turns on a dime and the pitch is super responsive. The glide on the ART is notable and average speed was a little higher (although top speed was on the HPS) but in pitch and yaw I found it so much less responsive. I can turn the ART pretty hard but it requires a lot more effort which adds up over a longer downwinder. I guess in open ocean swell where you have long rollers the ART would be superior due to speed and glide but for my local where a more aggressive style is needed I don't love it.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Tuan Lam on ART 999 riding style: I prefer gliding on the bumps with the 999 rather than going full speed down the face, it has a lot of front foot then but it is manageable if you step forward a bit or put mast backward. For carving in waves, 999 is not a snappy wing to carve especially rail to rail, but once you get used to it and bank into the turn, it turns very well. It is just more of a longboard style turning than short board. It needs more body engagement into the turn, and also back foot steering.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Kent Wright (90kg) on ART 999: My first Downwinder with 999 was epic, plenty of wind and swell. Breached once at first whilst playing around then not once in the run. All km splits were over 25kph average and no breaches at all. Using unshimmed 380 rear on short fuse 860 carbon mast. High aspect foils heavily affected by weed or white water turbulence. However in clean downwind conditions they are great.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Rob Pirie on HPS vs ART: I replaced my 999 with a 930 HPS and never looked back. For prone and ding. I swap between the 420 & 380 for higher winds and bigger waves.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Andy Corbe on HPS 930 vs 880: I rode the 930 and 880 in the same session the other day, the 930 had considerably more glide and only felt a tiny bit slower if at all. I think its my favourite right now. If you want a little more roll and speed go 880, if you want a bit more glide and pump go 930.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Matthew Roney on HPS 880 for 87kg rider: at 87kg, I think you'd find an 880 hard to link multiple waves. If pumping and linking waves to the max is your thing, id go the next one up.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Mike Siddells (82kg) on ART999 + HPS1050 combo: yes I have this combo. Is brilliant, haven't used the 1010 since getting the 1050 some months back. Complements the ART999 very well.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - ART vs HPS Thread

posts.text: Thomas Gelet (72kg, 46yo) - BSC 1060 dock start first impression: Around 1200 dockstart attempts experience. The 1060 is easy, my backfoot position is never perfect when I jump, but the glide is good, it give the time to adjust and find the tail pad. It is easy to reach the good speed which is much higher than my old one. Used it with the standard fuse, 460 stab and 80 cm carbon mast. I think the short or ultrashort fuse will suit my style better. I like fast tempo on my back foot with less pressure. Clearly it is a higher performance foil compared to my learning one. 15 successful starts for 10 fails.

Adrian Roper (Foil Life Podcast 2026) on Tempo accessibility: I've had a lot of guys riding them that are not necessarily advanced and they actually find it no harder than the Fireball to use but much, much faster. Not only for the full on races but for everybody in between as well.

Adrian Roper on Tempo maneuverability design: As they get more and more high aspect there's actually retaining some chord in the middle here so that it's really well attached and then making the tips narrower. Whenever you make the tips narrower and wider in here, you actually reduce the second moment of area for roll. So it allows the wing to turn from side to side really nicely. That's actually a really nice surf wing which is not what you would imagine it could be.

Adrian Roper on Fatty Mast stiffness comparison (25kg side load bend test): Aluminium 19mm bends 38mm, Power Carbon 29mm, High Modulus 22mm, Ultra 19mm, Fatty (18.1mm thick) only 11.7mm. So it's another leg of stiffness. Because it's thick, we don't have to build it out of ridiculously high modulus carbon so the mast is actually not that expensive.

Adrian Roper on 1750 pump wing requirements: The biggest market for this whole fatty fuse, fatty mast system will be with heavier riders with biggest span wings. It'll give them a level of control that they've never experienced with winging.

Adrian Roper on Gold Logo Ultra Pro mast: This is absolute minimum drag, minimum thickness, only 11mm through the bottom. Really only for say less than 90kg, riding the tempo range of wings. It's not for dock start with big wings.

Adrian Roper mast selection guidance (2026): It's now time to think about how heavy you are, what you're planning to do with that mast, what wing you're going to be using, and buying the appropriate mast and fuselage setup to work with that.

Jon McCabe on Surge 830 tuning (February 4, 2026): Just had my first crack in the waves on the 830 surge with ultrashort fuse and 300 surf skinny! Found +1 tail shim to be super balanced and was blown away with my turns and confidence on the first take off. I think people should talk more about their shim preferences on different combos.

Jon McCabe on shim recommendations for Surge: try +1 tail shim on 300 and +0.5 on 320 and pitchy goes away. The positive shim takes load off the back leg and lets you weight the front foot more, which puts me in a stronger, more athletic stance. I can ride more aggressively, lean into turns with confidence. The key is finding the smallest shim that lets you stand naturally with equal fatigue on both legs after a good session.

Mark Shinn on Surge setup: The Surge definitely likes a more forward mast position and this is generally a more effective change than shimming the mast (but that of course depends a lot on the board you are using). The Ultrashort Adv+ seems to be the go to for most riders on the Surge right now. I have always been a fan of the Crazy short for wave riding but having seen what Luke Atkinson can do on the Ultra I have changed my mind!

Ian Sloan (75kg) on Surge shims at La Ventana: I played around a bunch and found I really liked a +1 or +0.5 stab shim for riding waves. It felt like it pumped a bit easier, I was able to get the board up higher in the water column. It also seemed to glide a bit longer on the waves. Smaller waves were better with +1 and bigger waves better +0.5. This was my experience with both the Surge 830 and my AV2 879. Using either 320 or 300 Surf Skinny stab.
Adrian Roper on shims: even the +.25 shim makes a big difference. You can be quite subtle with your testing. Nothing wrong with shims and it does help dial the feel in for different riders

Shannon Stent (70kg) - Surge 830 parawing setup: 18km downwind run on the west coast of Australia! Conditions were solid 20kn. Setup: Ozone Pocket Rocket 3.6, AXIS Surge 830 with 280 Surf Skinny, Advance+ Ultra Short fuse, 80cm Pro Carbon Mast, Sunova 56 Coaster (60L).

Shannon Stent on Surge 830 for downwind (January 30, 2026): I know some of you have been asking about Surge for downwind. Well I've been using it a lot recently, namely the 830 with the 280 Surf Skinny. It blows me away how fun and user friendly it is, especially for parawing and the lower volume board. It just feels like surfing the endless wave. I don't use a shim at all mate, and I'm using the Advance + Ultra Short fuse.

Jon McCabe on Surge sizing for DW: 890 has been magical for DW for me but I want to unlock the 830 next. I was tail heavy on the 300 surf skinny on my first 830 dw run, sounds like I need to play more with mast position.
Mark Shinn on Surf Skinny 320 + ART Pro 1201 pairing: Unfortunately NO. Crashes are 99% pilot error. Actually I think that is a very nice pairing.... The 320 loosens up the 1201 a little.

Jimmy Jam Foils on Surf Skinny vs regular Skinny: Doing tow in lessons this week on Oahu in overhead surf, the skinny 55 did have more stability than the surf 320 for a student of mine. I do love the surf skinnies and really spices up the turning and worth the switch. But it is a hair less stable

Ben Comber (~70kg) - Surge 890 vs Spitfire 840 first comparison (December 29, 2025): Fun to jump on the surge for the first time. Still need to jump back on the spitfire 840 for the final comparison but instantly felt the much easier and faster pump. Definitely a bit more roll although the surf skinny was making a big difference as well I reckon. Setup: Surge 890 + advance crazyshort + surf skinny 300. Thinking the surge 830 could be the perfect size for me at just under 70kg.

Ian Sloan (75kg) on Surge 830 replacing Spitfire: 75kg and been riding the 830. Unless I'm trying to wing in single digit winds I don't need any bigger. Awesome foil. Sadly I didn't even bring my Spitfire 840 to La Ventana. I just didn't think I would ride it now I have the Surge...

Luke Atkinson on Surge 890 (December 19, 2025): Long rides at home. Riding the Surge 890 with Surf Skinny 300 here. The full clips shows how well these foils pump glide and are the ultimate foil. It really is the ultimate foil for me. Running 80 UHM mast.

Mark Shinn on Surf Skinny vs regular Skinny sizing: I think the 320 surf skinny has similar or more tail lift to the skinny 45 so if you change you would be looking at the 300 or 280... but that's for wave use. For DW or flat water the regular skinny might be a better option.

Dimitris Apalagakis (73kg) on ART v2 819 setup: 73kg here and using the Art v2 819 for winging. I pair it with the Surf Skinny 300 and Ultra Short fuse and works fantastic. Depending on your sport and conditions you can go for either 300 or 320. Both will do, but for looseness and hard turns definitely the 300. For a bit more stability and low end, or if you use shorter fuse the 320.

Michael Scholes on stab sizing for ART v2 819 at 80kg: I'd recommend a smaller skinny such as the 358/35 or if wanting the surf skinny definitely the 300/45 as the 320/48 still produces a lot of lift.

Cimeron (female, learning parawing): I've found the Surge 830 to be the friendliest for me since it's so stable, the camber gets me up on foil faster, and when I'm overpowered the 830 slows things down so I can control the foil and prevent a full-detonation breach. For me, the Surge 830 has been easier than the ART v2 819 and 879 (which need a lot more speed to get up on foil), the Fireball 1070 (too big for me - instant catapult the second I'd get on foil), the Spitfire 780, and the Surge 740 (which was less stable than the 830).
MargauxH (female, French): I learn V1 parawing with a PNG 1300! Stability is the key for me. Also: 1070 fireball I agree, loving it!

Brittany Ayers (female): 1070 Fireball is my fave. Its only 877 cm2. It gives sooo much glide which helps if youre in smaller swell and trying to connect bumps. In Hood I've been on the 1020 tempo in the bigger bumps. Since it has such a big wing span it can be a little tricky coming from a 620 spittie or small ART v2. It only needs a little feedback to turn or carve. Once you dial it in its pure magic! Especially if you are packing your parawing away.

Brittany Ayers (female) on Spitfire 780 vs Fireball 1070: And if you can hold down a 780 Spitfire you can on the 1070. The 780 has a larger actual area than the 1070 fireball. Once you unlock it you will love it! Just think less is more! A little finesse is the way.
Holly Pye (female, UK): I also love the fireball for parawinging. The glide helps to give you extra time to stash the parawing. Excited to try the Surge for the first time very soon too.

Olivia Piana (female, pro foiler) on learning parawing: When I started last summer I learned with the art v2 999 if I remember well, with a 3.8 and like 15/20knots so low-end parawing conditions. It's definitely a new thing! Not as easy as wingfoiling. Now the goal is to use the parawing to get out in the ocean with my sup setup (tempo 960).

Lena (female, Austria, competitor): Competing at the boot düsseldorf in the pumpfoil event, actually riding the fireball 1350 and not sure which is the best option for the pool. Has somebody tested the surge 1010 for pumpfoiling?

Olivia Piana on Surge 1010 vs Fireball for pool pumpfoiling: For the pool a lower aspect ratio would be definitely better. 1010 kind of the same lift as the 1070 fireball (Yvon from France said that).

Gabriella / Gabi Eliah Bella (female) on Surge 780 setup: I've been enjoying the 780 Surge with the ultra short advanced + and 320 surf skinny.. feels really playful but still stable. I tend to prefer the feel of the bigger rear wings for wave riding but I'd like to give the 300 surf skinny another go to see which one I prefer. You can't go wrong with either of those options.

Gabriella on 280 stab with Surge 780: Yes think if you are already riding the 280 on other foils you will love it on the 780! if you want more lift out of the setup but prefer the feel of the little stabs you can easily try adding in .5 Degree of black shim and see how that feels.
Luke Atkinson (100kg) on Surf Skinny 300 with Surge: Dunno about the comparison but I find the 300 surf skinny perfect for me at 100kg. Plenty of pump to it.

Ry Stack on Surge 890 for prone: Just got the surge 890, been pairing with the 35 skinny for prone. Asking about a surf skinny that would preserve roughly same level pump/glide/speed of 35 skinny but give better turning. Also: towing behind an efoil, tow boogie style.

Paul Hurley on Surge 830 + Surf Skinny 300/45 with hand wing: Its feels great but very nervous when the water is a bit messy and the board tends to nosedive the odd time, maybe i need to move the mast?

Glenn Wade (95kg) on Surge 1010 maiden voyage: I'm 95kg & have been riding Spitfires 1030, 960 & 900 on an Advanced + short fuselage, 300 surf skinny stab with a Sunova 5'3" 50L board with a Gen2 FD. I was stoked with the Surge in 2' waves but felt that the mast position needed to go forward a bit. It seemed like I had to lean back on the board with lots of back foot pressure to keep the nose up, especially on bottom turns.

Mark Shinn on Surge mast positioning: In short - yes, you need to move the mast forward a little. If you were coming from the Fireball you would be used to it already. I suspect it is the high camber profile. When properly set the Surge should feel completely neutral between your 2 feet... and one of the beauties of that foil is that the pressure doesn't shift when your speed changes, once you find your stance you can stay there whether sat on a swell waiting for it to build or dropping into a fast moving steep section.

Mark Shinn on Fireball vs ART v2 mast position: Depending a little on the sport you are doing I think the Fireball prefers to be a couple of cm further forwards in the box than the ART v2. if you are strapless then this is easy to achieve on the fly by simply moving your feet.

Hal Turner on switching from Spitfire to Surge 950: been riding the Spitfire's 960/900/840 for a few months. When I switched to the new surge 950 it was almost impossible to keep the nose up. I had to put the mast all the way forward 2 inches further to make it level out. A couple of sessions in and I'm loving it.

Harris Chang on Surge 830 stab tuning: I was on a sf840 and skinny 50 tail. i picked up the surge 830 and I felt like too much back foot pressure. Mast was all the way forward already. Went to the skinny 55 and it seem to balance things out. I already had both tails so was an easy swap.
Mark Shinn on Surge accessibility: My 11 year old son has been Foil Driving all summer on the spitfires but I put him on the Surge and he loved it... said he found everything easier on it.
Sean Richardson on Surge 830 stab choice: I went back to my progressive 300 with my 830 and got much more hold when dropping into bigger waves.

Grant Neill on ART to Surge 950 transition with Foil Drive: I have the same experience going from Art 999 and 1099 to Surge 950 with foil drive. At low speed it is ok but at higher speed in waves the nose wants to dive a lot. Changed tail from skinny 360 to 350 progressive which is much bigger... this helped a lot but still not as balanced across the speed range as the Art v2's. Going to try moving the mast forward a little and keeping my stance the same.
Mark Fisher on Surge nose-down fix: Mast forward or feet back a bit, a mast shim can help if your board tends to ride nose down too.

Sveny Foils (115kg) on Fatty gear review (December 11, 2025): THE FATTY GEAR to a test. Setup: 80 Fatty Mast and the Ultra Short Fatty Fuse on a 950 Surge with a 320 Surf Skinny. I was really impressed with how fast it still goes. I hit over 34 km per hour on a surfy downwind run. It does feel a little harder or draggier to get the foil up, but once you are riding it feels super solid. There is definitely a bit more drag compared to the Ultra High Modulus Mast. With the UHM you can fly higher and it accelerates a lot quicker. The Fatty Mast is slower and you need to pump it more. You cannot really overtake bumps with it. But to be honest I actually like that. You can stay on a bump or a swirl really nicely and just keep surfing it. You are not overrunning it or going too fast. It gives you a different kind of downwind feeling because you can slow it down easily and really surf the energy. The only downside is if you miss a bump or want to overtake one, that is something the Fatty Mast does not really allow. The UHM can do that, no problem. But otherwise I am really impressed with how the Fatty gear works, especially for heavier riders like me at 115kg. I am loving it.

Adrian Roper on Fatty mast for 115kg rider: I think 950 Surge and your weight the Ultra PRO would feel better as you have said. Where it would really excel is if you were riding say a 1250 Fireball. With that I doubt you would notice the drag but for sure you would feel the added control.

Mark Shinn on ART v2 vs Surge: The ART v2 is still a great foil but in a wave environment the Surge is just a better foil! If you do alot of winging on flatter water then the v2 is still a very viable option - fast and playful but if you are in the waves you are probably going to wanna swap.
Sebastian Lampen (75kg) asking for prone Surge size: I weigh 75kg, decent prone rider. Goal is to be a wing that I can link 4/5 waves on. Thinking 830.
Adrian Roper on Surge 950 for 75kg prone rider: 950 should be perfect. On Surf Skinny 320 vs 300: either fine. Depends on balance you prefer. 320 more stable 300 looser turning.

Sveny Foils on Surge vs Fireball: If you wanna have fun and have a surfy dw surge 950 and surf skinny 320. If you just wanna shoot dw fireball. Also I found it way easier going upwind on a surge instead of a fireball.

Jake Leichtling (108kg) asking for Surge sizing - Bay Area: I'm in the Bay Area with consistent 15-25 knot winds. My daily driver is the ARTv2 999 and Skinny 362. I'm looking for a Surge + SurfSkinny setup to take out in 18+ knot winds, when there's more wind swell to surf. In these conditions, my current setup feels like it's got a bit too much lift. Setup: no shims, advance+ ultrashort fuse, 6'6" midlength board, 90cm carbon mast. Been foiling for 2.5 years and am an early intermediate.
Thomas Roberts (82kg) on Surge 890 sizing: I'm 82 kg and settled on 890. I got to demo the 950/890 and there is a smaller one too. They're super fun man. They will go great in channel swell at 3rd.

Doug D PFoiler on Fireball vs Surge for heavy riders in Bay Area: heaps of hrs on both the 1070 and 1250 fireball and similar wt. For Bay Area with what you want to do and not really ocean breaking wave riding I would seriously consider the FB for the glide and good handling for such a HA wing. the 1070 for 20 kts is real nice for us big guys I really like it but need 17 kts so that's why I have the 1250 for lighter days and parawing. but for in the bay might be a better choice FB series, just don't think your going to get the speed/glide out of the surge compared to the FB that comes in handy in bay relatively flatter conditions.

Thomas Roberts on Fireball vs Surge use case: If you want to be able to flag it and ride downwind from Coyote to 3rd, you want the Fireball on the Adv+ Ultrashort. If you want to cruise around looking for the biggest bumps, flag it and carve wrap around cutbacks in both directions, you want the surge.

Mark Shinn on Surge 950 for 108kg rider: Adrian is correct of course... the 950 is the closest size for size, probably the 320 Surf Skinny paired with it on - should be perfect on that ADV + Ultra short fuse. If you want pure downwind then probably the 1070 Fireball will do the same job but get you there a little quicker but your comment 'gybing back and forth' sounds suspiciously like carving and that means Surge all the way. Also: in terms of starting the 950 lifts a little earlier than the 999 in 18 kn plus you would be more than fine on the 890.

Sveny Foils on ART v2 vs Surge vs Fireball positioning: For me personally, I don't really feel the need for the ART v2 anymore. The Surge just covers everything the V2 does, but for my style it does it better. You still get the speed and efficiency, but with the added surf-style feel and way more freedom to turn. A lot of my mates have ended up replacing their V2s with a Surge as well, so that kind of says it all. Some people still love their V2s, and that's totally fine, but for my riding the Surge does the whole job and lets you actually surf the foil too. It's definitely not a Fireball with that full-on glide. It just comes down to what you want to do — pure glide or more surf-style downwinding and prone surf etc
Matthew Ross (95kg) on kiting foil choice: 760 and the 360 surf skiing. I had the art 819 but it was not great in turbulent water. I could go smaller as well. 95kg.

Hal Turner (82kg) on Surge sizing: I was riding the 950. I wanted the 890 but it's not coming until the next shipment. I also got the 830 because it was available, but it might be a little small. I would call myself and intermediate riding mostly small to shoulder high waves. 82 kg.

Hal Turner on Surge vs Spitfire first impression: Tried it today first time. A bit of a learning curve. Had to move mast forward a couple inches. was wanting to nose dive a bit. Different than my spitfire. Started figuring it out by second battery. longer glide, better pumping and turning. just needed to adapt.
Jimmy Jam Foils on Surge sizing: grabbed the 950 and 1010 for now. trying to get that 830 for tow foiling on oahu this winter.

Chris Middleton on Surge vs ART v2 790 for prone (November 17, 2025): First prone session on the new Surge and surf skinny. Really impressed, this setup has amazing glide, speed and stability. Like the ART v2 790 I rode prior this, tip breach is no problem, but unlike the ART v2 and Skinny 45, my Surge and Surf Skinny, has better low end, better acceleration, better stability through turns and gives me more confidence linking waves in deeper water, further out. I noticed it will lift easier and stay higher which is super important in prone riding, but what i love is carving through turns with confidence. I'm so stoked right now. Well done Axis team.
Jon Verhoek on Surf Skinny vs Progressive 300: Surf 320. The 300 feels smaller.
Vangelis Evan Mavridoglou on Surge: It's my favorite foil for everything I do. And yes, the surf skinny rears are a must no matter which front wing.

Jacob Matan (Top contributor) on Surf Skinny 320/48 (November 17, 2025): After my first session on the surf skinny 320/48 I am calling it, this is my only tail wing from now on. it's that perfect sweet spot between the progressives and skinny's. I was doing upwind downwind on the parawing with SF 1180, small but fun rippable bumps. Similar speed and low drag as my 362/50 skinny but way better turning. Previously I was swapping between the progressives 325 for wing and sup in waves and skinny 362/50 for wing and parawing in bumps/downwind but I think the surf skinny will just do both jobs better.

Kent Wright on Surf Skinny 320/48 with Fireball 1250: I did my first downwinder yesterday with the 320/48 surf skinny. Using it with the 1250fb and ultrashort+ in light cruisey conditions. I have 35,45 & 55 skinny's but my usual go too is the 360/45. Fairly sure my go to will now be the 320/48 surf skinny, it felt great.
Eddie Hawley (80kg) on Surf 300 as only stab: Agree, I am 80kg and the surf 300 is the only stab I use for winging, prone and wake foiling. Great job.

Matthew Kyhnn (75kg) asking for surf skinny size: What size surf skinny would you all suggest for 75 kgs? I normally wing a 939 and Foil Drive a 900. Sveny Foils response: you can't go wrong on the 300.

Jon Verhoek (92kg) on Surf Skinny 300 vs 320: I own 320, good mate the 300 and they both have their place depending on conditions. My initial feel is they respond well to energy in the water. If it's flat, go bigger. Also 92kgs because I think that does matter.
Andrew Caska on Surf Skinny 320: It's also my favourite. I have the smaller one as well, but for surfing the 320 is epic.

Mark Shinn on simplified stab quiver: I agree with your comments but prefer the Surf Skinny 300 for most situations... I still use the skinny 40 for low energy DW conditions where I am not gonna be turning alot but for pretty much anything else I am on the SS300. Makes like pretty easy as I only need Skinny 40, Surf Skinny 300 and an Alu Tail pipe for the T~I Link.

Stephen Westwood (85kg) asking about Surf Skinny 300 vs 320: I can't decide between the 320 and 300 SS to use on my ARTv2 999/879, FD 1070, Spitfire 960/840. I currently mainly use the 350 Progressive and 45 Skinny and also have the 300P and 40 Skinny. I'm 85kg. If you could pick one SS what is it and why?

Bruce Kropelin on Surf Skinny 300 vs 320: I'd suggest going the 300 with the Art V2's. I was out yesterday in bigger conditions & the 300 had excellent control along with the speed. I used the 320 with the FB1000 it wasn't as good. Lot's of glide but not as agile.

Andy Corbe on Surf Skinny 300: Loving the 300, feels a little smaller than the prog 300 but has the efficiency of a smaller skinny whilst keeping complete traction in the turns. If you're coming from a 350 you may want to start with a larger size but probably you'd soon get used to the 300.

Ian Sloan (75kg) on Surf Skinny 320SS: I recently started riding with the 320SS and I'm loving it! Coming from P350 and S45, 40, 35... Winging and wake foil. 75kg. It feels like the progressive but way faster. Tons of control even though the area of the SS is quite small. Since I started riding it I don't want to put the regular Skinny back on. The P350 I was already only using for wake or light wind winging. I'll probably get the 300SS before my trip to LV in January.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread

posts.text: Bruce Kropelin on Surf Skinny 300 with Fireball 1000: I also ran the 300SS with my FB1000 & was delighted with the control and more speed/glide. The SS gives you unbelievable control.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread

posts.text: Eddie Hawley (80kg) on Surf 300 setup for surf: I use the surf 300 with the small spitfires in the surf. The 350p was too slow and the 40 skinny was different to turn without sliding out of the turn, but fast. The surf 300, ultrashort A+ fuse, 960 spitfire or 1070 fireball for a 80kg rider in waist to head high surf is perfect. So much control and fast glide.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread

posts.text: Eddie Hawley on why Surf Skinny 300 over 320: As Adrian Roper talks about in many podcasts and interviews that span is one of the most important features of a foil and I agree with that theory. So for personal progression reasons I wanted an approximately 300mm span stabilizer and the 300 surf skinny was the final choice. The shape of the surf skinnys are concave (not flat like the skinny or progressive range) so because of this it is very stable.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread

posts.text: Luke Atkinson (100kg) on Surf Skinny 300 for surf: At 100kg the 300 is my go to for surf. It pumps better than progressive range and turns better than the skinny range. Using Ultrashort adv+ fuse.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread

posts.text: Jon Verhoek on Surf Skinny equivalents: 320SS feels like p300 made love to 45skinny. 350p feels relatively bigger and slower but a reasonable amount. 300SS feel like 35skinny speed wise and maybe 275p might feel like but haven't actually ridden a 275 personally.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread

posts.text: Bruce Kropelin on Surf Skinny 300 & 320: I went with the 300 & 320. I should have got the 280 for my FB for more speed. Last year I bought several Skinny's & was kind of disappointed, so continued Progressives as well. These SS were special, & I noticed it right away. Should have bought 280 too! Unbelievable difference with two wings I ride frequently the FB & Art V2.
posts.source: FB Screenshot 2026-02-12 - Stephen Westwood SS Thread
